73995: Soratami Mindsweeper.author: Lateralis0ne
73995: Soratami Mindsweeper.text_parsed:
I had a Moonfolk Mill deck that I was putting together that abused this card.

Decklist:

Lands: 17

10 Island
1 Urza's Tower
1 Urza's Mine
1 Urza's Power Plant
4 Cloudpost

Creatures: 12

2 Patron of the Moon
4 Soratami Mindsweeper
3 Trinket Mage
2 Floodbringer
1 Meloku the Clouded Mirror

Spells: 31

3 Amulet of Vigor
4 Aether Spellbomb
4 Expedition Map
4 Ponder
4 Quest of Ancient Secrets
4 Boomerang
4 Treasure Hunt

Basically, get the pieces out, then mill in one turn. Lots of bounce, card recursion, cheap search tech for lands other than basic types, and card draw. You'd be surprised how consistent it was. Had to take it apart for some of the cards, but I might put it together sometime down the road and turn it into a Fish deck of sorts.

73995: Soratami Mindsweeper.author: JuzamDjimmy
73995: Soratami Mindsweeper.text_parsed:
I think this is a great EDH/Commander card!

It can protect your expensive "one of" lands from "Land Destruction" while punishing your opponent by milling two cards for trying, all this and it can be tapped or untapped to activate.

It can get rid of Sensei's Divining Top once it's on top of a library.

It can counter a miracle card that was tutored for and placed on top of a deck, or other such top deck strategy.

It can work in conjunction with many come into play effect land cards like Bajuka Bog, Vesuva, Halimar Depths, Teetering Peaks, The life gain lands, etc.

You can use it with Tolarian Academy or Gaea's Cradle by tapping for mana, then returning playing again, then tapping again!

Landfall implications have already been mentioned.

All this with a four toughness (hard to kill with damage) flier! No one really wants to kill this guy so he flies under the radar most of the time. Pretty tech utility Creature that only has one blue in its cost!

74006: Mark of the Oni.author: OmegaSerris
74006: Mark of the Oni.text_parsed:
Everyone (save for a few) is focusing solely on the one sentence of this card. This can simply be used as a color shifted Threaten/Act of Treason (minus the untap/haste). And how do we break those cards? Sacrifice effects! And has SO MANY more of those than . The Demon line is actually a benefit, not a downside. I read this card as:

Mark of the Oni
Sorcery
Gain control of target creature until end of turn. If you control a Demon, gain control of target creature for as long as you control a Demon instead.

Of course, there are some technial differences, but you get my point. I don't like defending many of Kamigawa's cards, but they did pretty good on this one.
74006: Mark of the Oni.text_posted:
Everyone (save for a few) is focusing solely on the one sentence of this card. This can simply be used as a color shifted [autocard]Threaten[/autocard]/[autocard]Act of Treason[/autocard] (minus the untap/haste). And how do we break those cards? Sacrifice effects! And [B] has SO MANY more of those than [R]. The Demon line is actually a benefit, not a downside. I read this card as:

Mark of the Oni [2B]
Sorcery
Gain control of target creature until end of turn. If you control a Demon, gain control of target creature for as long as you control a Demon instead.

Of course, there are some technial differences, but you get my point. I don't like defending many of Kamigawa's cards, but they did pretty good on this one.

I just had my arse handed to me by this card, someone had a casual demon tribal deck and the cornerstone were many of the 4 mana demons such as Grinning Demon, Abyssal Persecutor and Scourge of Numai. Also had removals and sacrifice cards like Geth's Verdict

Had a hard time dealing with those demons as they have quite high toughness and are already black which means a majority of removal spells don't work. Using this card I had most of my blockers taken away for a cheap cost and control the board

4/5

74033: Walker of Secret Ways.author: Ladon---
74033: Walker of Secret Ways.text_parsed:
I read an article that mentioned how to use her second ability in a clever way. In the case that you have more attackers than your opponent has defenders, once your opponent has declared blockers, it's not unlikely that he/she has blocked your Ninja. Return those blocked Ninja to your hand, then Ninjutsu them in using the attackers your opponent chose not to block. This ability is also useful if your opponent chooses to cast his Instant-Speed removal on your Ninja after the Declare Attackers Phase, but before the Declare Blockers Phase (because during that phase the unblocked ninjas could be ninjutsu'd out to give the spell an illegal target before resolving). Back when combat damage went on the stack you could probably abuse the ability to that end also.

Rant: Ninjas were a small cycle. Only Blue and Black got them, and they were limited to two commons, one uncommon and one Rare of each color. Walker of the Secret Ways was the Blue uncommon Ninja, and though useful in certain situations thanks to her activated ability, her Combat Damage ability is very lackluster. In my opinion, considering how good Throat Slitter is as the Black uncommon Ninja, this card should have been something like "When Walker of the Secret Ways deals combat damage to a player, that player puts the top 5 cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard." That would have been totally badass, and had great synergy with Skullsnatcher and especially Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni. Mill is definitely blue, so it makes me kind of sad to have this chick as the only Ninja I simply cannot put in my Ninja deck.

74033: Walker of Secret Ways.author: En_Sigma
74033: Walker of Secret Ways.text_parsed:
@TheWallinator74

Some of you information seems to be off. It's about 25,000 years after the Kamigawa Kami War, which occurred long before Tetsuo Umezawa defeated Bolas on Madara. When Bolas escaped Tetsuo's prison, he swore vengeance on all the Umezawa clan and anyone instrumental in their victory. If we read the novels depicting the Kami War, Toshiro Umezawa was brought to Madara by the Myojin of Night's Reach. Bolas sought out Night's Reach -- defeating her, turning her followers against her, and destroying her realm, which -- it should be noted -- is not Kamigawa, or at least not in its entirety. We see that Kamigawa is still extant in Agents of Artifice, where Jace defeats Tezzeret -- long after Bolas's conflict with Night's Reach.

There you have it - hope yet for a revisit.

Why didn't you block? Why didn't you block? Why didn't you block?

74034: Sway of the Stars.author: Syngod
74034: Sway of the Stars.text_parsed:
@NeverendingDream,
The point of the EDH official "banned" list is to take out cards that take away some of the enjoyment in the format. In a format where you start at 4 life, this resets the board with 7 life. If you are running Jhoria, you can suspend a creature with power equal to or greater than 7 to kill someone the turn this hits play since you get to pick the order of play. The second reason is most likely not the reason it is "banned" in EDH, it is not very fun (apparently) to play against in EDH. It should be noted that the EDH "banned" list is a recommended list of cards to be banned in a social setting where not everyone is close friends etc.

74034: Sway of the Stars.author: DarthParallax
74034: Sway of the Stars.text_parsed:
It's a Time Reversal that doesn't exile itself, stapled to a Terminus that tucks the entire board and shuffles it away, stapled to Sorin Markov's -2 hitting everyone and dealing 3 extra.

I'm inclined to wonder if this might actually be more powerful than TimeTWISTER. It's 3x as slow...but it seems to be about 5x as much impact on the game.

I would like this and Time Stretch to each get Mythic Rare reprints sometime. Core Sets have recently given us 'Not Quite Power 9' cards as Mythics. Both of these seem worth reminding people of their existence.

74084: Mistblade Shinobi.author: Donovan_Fabian
74084: Mistblade Shinobi.text_parsed: I love the ability on this card, you can keep your opponents creatures off the field pretty easily just by giving mistblade flying or fear.  The ninjutsu ability really seals the deal though, if you have cards in your deck that read "when this card enters play.." x thing happens, then as long as you can get through one attack with it to your opponents life points you can return it to your hand and play it again the next turn and still bounce your opponents creature.  It also potentially lets you play this card a turn earlier for its ninjutsu cost.  Its only weakness is that its still a 1/1 for 3 mana, it might have been better as a 1/2, so it wouldn't die to other starting level creatures that only take 1 mana.

74084: Mistblade Shinobi.author: Nayban
74084: Mistblade Shinobi.text_parsed: This card is easily one of the strongest cards I have. If you can manage to get this past an opponents defenses, and have a second one in your hand, you can use Ninjutsu to bounce them back and forth, returning every creature an opponent controls. As for its Damage being low, just play Ronin Warclub or something else that has "Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under your control, attach Ronin Warclub to that creature." and you wil be doing 3 damage every time you bounce one.

74084: Mistblade Shinobi.author: Daijin26
74084: Mistblade Shinobi.text_parsed:
Actually Nayban that doesn't work. When you Ninjutsu in the second Shinobi after the first one dealt its combat damage, it would be too late for the second Shinobi to deal combat damage and bounce another creature. So there is no continuous bounce loop.

The most you could do is up to 2 times, having one Shinobi attacking and with first strike so that he would deal first strike combat damage and afterward during the first strike combat step, you Ninjutsu in the second Mistblade and he would be in play and attacking before the normal combat damage step, which will be in time for him to deal his own combat damage and bounce a second creature.

74084: Mistblade Shinobi.author: Ladon---
74084: Mistblade Shinobi.text_parsed:
@littleteapot: If you're using Ornithopters to Ninjutsu him in, then it really doesn't take a lot of work (or mana commitment) to Ninjutsu. Unsummon is a fantastic effect on this creature, and if you have multiples they can save eachother from removal on the mega cheap (just {U}? awesome!).

An early Mistblade Shinobi gives you a great tempo swing. Considering how mana-intensive ninjas are (and how crazy they get once you have that mana), sending your opponent's creatures back to their hands buys you the time you need to dominate the board. If you send their three mana creature back on turn three, they're in a tight spot come turn four when you could drop Higure, the Still Wind (and mess up their momentum even harder with unblockable Ninjas).

@Snaxme: I prefer Nether Traitor with this guy personally ;)

74087: Genju of the Fields.author: Mode
74087: Genju of the Fields.text_parsed:
I think AXER wasn't necessarily talking about the fact that this card used to read "gains lifelink until end of turn" for some time.
The Oracle states "its controller gains that much life", not "you gain that much life", as printed on the card. One might think that this makes a major difference when considering that you could cast this on an opponent's plains.
But in fact it does not make any since this phrase is considered to be part of the textbox for the enchanted creature, therefore refers to the creature's controller.
74087: Genju of the Fields.text_posted:
I think AXER wasn't necessarily talking about the fact that this card used to read "gains lifelink until end of turn" for some time.
The Oracle states "[i]its controller[/i] gains that much life", not "[i]you[/i] gain that much life", as printed on the card. One might think that this makes a major difference when considering that you could cast this on an opponent's plains.

74090: Sosuke's Summons.author: Mode
74090: Sosuke's Summons.text_parsed:
I agree with AlphaNumerical and Forgeling. And both changes would have made perfect sense flavorwise.

Regarding the instant speed, the two snakes depicted on the artworks are seen jumping down a tree for an ambush.
(There are barely any token generators at instant speed that deliver such a sudden appearance.)

Regarding the Warrior type, look at their fierce body language. You can tell they are experienced and eager to battle.
Oh. And each of them is wielding FOUR. FREAKING. KRISES.
Which comes at little surprise, considering they are summoned by Sosuke, Son of Seshiro, the Snake Warrior legend.
So it's reasonable to assume they are from the Kashi-Tribe, in which every snake is a warrior.

74097: Kami of False Hope.author: GrimjawxRULES
74097: Kami of False Hope.text_parsed:
Fantastic creature. Can be returned with Proclamation of Rebirth and searched for with Ranger of Eos to repeatedly ruin opponents' combat steps, eventually locking them out entirely at 6 mana where you can forecast Proclamation of Rebirth and return Kami of False Hope from your graveyard every turn.
Furthermore, the art on this card is amazing - I would love to see Kami of False Hope being featured as Wallpaper of the Week sometime.

One white mana for a creature that can be relevant throughout the entire game (well, save against milling and burn, which isn't very common in my local casual environment) is incredible, and the art is just awesome. 5/5 from me.

74100: Nourishing Shoal.author: tcollins
74100: Nourishing Shoal.text_parsed:
So much potential wasted here on the generic life gain spell... I agree +1/+1 counters would have been cool although I think it would have been too overpowered. However in defense of Wizards, the other "typical" {G} options would have been:

1. Putting creatures into play, which would have been insanely powerful, even exiling a {4} cost card would yield massive card advantage.
2. Giving a creature +X/+X, this would have mostly trumped Blazing Shoal and also would have been absolutely broken
3. Untapping / tutoring lands, even putting X / 2 lands into hand / play would be ridiculous.

From a design perspective, the only way any of the above 3 options would have worked would be if there was a restriction on the value of {X} (i.e. "{X} cannot be more than 5") which wouldn't have flowed very well with the rest of the cycle.

74100: Nourishing Shoal.author: Enelysios
74100: Nourishing Shoal.text_parsed:
Shining Shoal: Redirect damage, able to save yourself, kill an opponent or Eliminate a threat on the board.
Disrupting Shoal: Manaless counterspell, often worth losing card advantage to kill a combo. Great against common CMCs like or in legacy.
Sickening Shoal: Kill a creature, even an indestructible one, not the best, but can be solidly helpful.
Blazing Shoal: Power boost, banned in modern, potent damage tool early game by letting you discard an unneeded end game spell.

This is pretty unforgivably bad, so much worse than the rest of the cycle that its amazing. Giving up card advantage for life is never a good idea. Spring of life for one mana more is a pretty terrible option too, but probably the only way you would use this card. If you are losing so badly that you need to spend 2 cards to gain some life, you are probably not going to come back from doing so. Worse, this card is painfully awful if you don't happen to have something huge in hand. Green does have more big things than most colors, but life-gain is such a weak effect that I cannot think of a situation where I would play this without some kind of awkward 3 or 4 card combo.

+1/+1 counters would have been a bad idea, that would have been way too powerful. Blazing shoal is good enough, and it is just a temporary boost to power. What would I have done?

Fallow Shoal
Instant -- Arcane
You may exile a green card with converted mana cost X from your hand rather than pay Fallow Shoal's mana cost.
Put target non-creature permanent with converted mana cost X or less on top of its owner's library.

Is the ability to put a land on top of your opponent's library for too good? It may actually be, the mana cost is cheaper than Fallow Earth, though more green intense. Plus the additional options, might be as cheap as such an effect could go, but that doesn't exactly fit with the cycle, does it?

74113: Toils of Night and Day.author: marchingent
74113: Toils of Night and Day.text_parsed:
Don't think of this card as simply 2 Twiddles. This is just as situational a card as Twiddle is, but may target all types of permanents and not just artifacts, creatures and lands. This is a powerful 1-on-1 card especially if you manage to draw 1st. When targeting land you are in essence making this card a blue Silence.

I have recently begun playing MtG again after a 10 year break and I can tell you that there are only a few cards that my opponents have openly commented mid-game on how frustrating a card is. This is one of them. I would recommend using this card and then reevaluating whether or not you think it is just "2 Twiddles" or is "not strong/useful".

Oh, and don't forget this card is arcane and can contribute to other cards needing arcane to boost it's own effectiveness.

74117: Three Tragedies.author: Atali
74117: Three Tragedies.text_parsed:
This card is NOT overcosted. Compare Fugue, Mindstab, and Hypnotic Cloud.

The issue is really that discard effects at-cost become undesirable above "discard two." In a dedicated discard deck, your opponent probably won't have three cards in hand by the time you can cast this, and in any other type of deck, you're more likely to use smaller discard that you can control (like Duress) rather than going for sheer number of cards to discard.

74122: Ronin Cliffrider.author: Mode
74122: Ronin Cliffrider.text_parsed:
Good combo tech indeed. I just wish it wouldn't cost 5...

In Eternal Formats you can most often already do something similar with that amount (or at least with the amount that's needed when you pay for the other card you want to use with the ronin).
Most of these combos also work better with Goblin Sharpshooter, who only costs

Quietus Spike is the exception, and will do a decent job. The problem is just the huge amount of mana this costs you when your opponent uses removal. (Sounds silly, but it's really a difference if you have to pay 5 and twice 3 mana, or just 3, 1 and 2 (with the Sharpshooter and Basilisk Collar for example. Consider that a combo that uses that much mana already can win you the game.)
And killing your opponent just with will take you multiple turns, especially when he can come up with chump blockers, which increases the chances that he'll eventually draw a removal spell.

Fire ants ( again) can do better with Charisma if you don't worry about your opponent's flyers and your own creatures with only 1 toughness (excluding BoP).

The combo with Neko-Te is a nice block-constructed one, though.

People seem to be all hung up on this card. "Oh, it's a bad Force of Will. Oh, it'll never be *insert counter here*. Waaah, it's a Kamigawa card, it sucks."

Come on people. It's right there in front of you! Any counter - ANY COUNTER - that you can cast while tapped out is good. If you know your opponent runs Disrupting Shoal, you're going to be more cautious about your plays from there on out. And if you're the one using the Shoal, that's exactly the kind of feeling you want to instill in your opponent.

74410: Forked-Branch Garami.author: VDZx
74410: Forked-Branch Garami.text_parsed:
@GradiustheFox
First of all, 8 mana worth of Spirits. Spirits generally aren't the best creatures for attacking. In a dedicated Kamigawa-style Spirit deck (I play one, it includes this), you usually aren't short on cards but are always short on mana, and you want to play as many Spirits as possible to get 'whenever you play a Spirit or Arcane spell' triggers, or just to have more stuff to sacrifice. As such, Forked-Branch Garami's CMC of 5 mana is quite a lot.

For card advantage through returning Spirits from your graveyard, a card like Death Denied is a lot better. It can fetch *any* creature, usually nets more creatures than Garami (at Garami's CMC, it returns 3), and it works even if you don't have a sacrifice outlet. Being an Arcane spell, it also triggers Spirit/Arcane triggers, and it can be returned using Hana Kami (and, funnily enough, Death Denied can then return Hana Kami). If you absolutely need the 4/4 body or don't have black, I'd advise going up one mana and going for Iname, Life Aspect instead (though that one can't be recycled, generally speaking).

I still play Forked-Branch Garami in my soulshift deck, but it's not exactly one of the most useful cards, not nearly as impressive as it seems at first.
74410: Forked-Branch Garami.text_posted:
@GradiustheFox
First of all, 8 mana worth of Spirits. Spirits generally aren't the best creatures for attacking. In a dedicated Kamigawa-style Spirit deck (I play one, it includes this), you usually aren't short on cards but are always short on mana, and you want to play as many Spirits as possible to get 'whenever you play a Spirit or Arcane spell' triggers, or just to have more stuff to sacrifice. As such, Forked-Branch Garami's CMC of 5 mana is quite a lot.

For card advantage through returning Spirits from your graveyard, a card like [autocard]Death Denied[/autocard] is a lot better. It can fetch *any* creature, usually nets more creatures than Garami (at Garami's CMC, it returns 3), and it works even if you don't have a sacrifice outlet. Being an Arcane spell, it also triggers Spirit/Arcane triggers, and it can be returned using [autocard]Hana Kami[/autocard] (and, funnily enough, Death Denied can then return Hana Kami). If you absolutely need the 4/4 body or don't have black, I'd advise going up one mana and going for [autocard]Iname, Life Aspect[/autocard] instead (though that one can't be recycled, generally speaking).

I still play Forked-Branch Garami in my soulshift deck, but it's not exactly one of the most useful cards, not nearly as impressive as it seems at first.

74412: Tallowisp.author: Mode
74412: Tallowisp.text_parsed:
This is a staple card for some great constructed fun!
A 1/3 two-drop that provides card advantage for every Spirit or Arcane spell is splendid.
Cheap and effective one-drop auras à la Rancor in particular do a great job with this guy - especially if you run Auratog.
Nature's Chosen is less known, but another neat pick here.
The auras can also be used to cast Shoals (or Force of Will) without paying mana.
If you add Dryads like Argothian Enchantress, you'll have even more card advantage - in particular if you grab a bounce-Aura like Flickering Ward.
Now with Rise of the Eldrazi we have a new great ássortment of cards for this guy, for example Umbras with totem armor like the one-drop Hyena Umbra; or Kor Spiritdancer, an incredible enchantress for Auras.

74415: Shuko.author: kiseki
74415: Shuko.text_parsed:
Most equipment look dull in comparison to bonesplitter. If you already have 4 of those, this isn't a bad addition to an equipment deck. With the exception of kor duelist, nearly every creature that gets a bonus buff from wearing equipment can be equipped with O-Naginata after equipping shuko. This can be a one turn tempo boost, and it increases the frequency of an early O-Naginata equip.
When you put four equipment on a creature, and it gets killed, you usually have a monster again pretty quick, and yet I always have a piece of a equipment just sitting around. This helps you get the mana requirement down for a massive re-equip. Also, when you tap out to equip a creature that ultimately dies, you can re-equip these to your other guys so that they get their equipment buff for defense.
And the duelist won't sneer at this either since shuko will cause it to do 2 extra damage.

74417: Blessing of Leeches.author: MechaKraken
74417: Blessing of Leeches.text_parsed:
@ takenbyshadow

Yes, I have learned my previous mistakes about sacrifice and regeneration effects. Since my last post, I have played more and learned a lot. I understand that the primary focus of this enchantment is to keep combo piece or win-con creatures alive, such as Blood Artist, deathbringer thoctar, or Lord of Lineage.

Anyway, let me make it up to everyone by providing better ideas for Blessing of Leeches.

Blessing of Leeches + one of the following...

High Priest of Penance = either unblockable 2 damage or one of the opponents permanents gets destroyed and you keep your creature =). Works well with Prey Upon

Saber Ants = lots of tokens on the field. Works best when you block with the ants, and then flash in Blessing of Leeches to preserve the ants while still getting your tokens =)

Spitemare / Boros Reckoner = damage reflection. The best part is that you can block whatever you want now that they can regenerate for free!

Nested Ghoul = more tokens on the field. The nested ghoul can keep taking punishment now that it has free regeneration, netting you a 2/2 zombie creature everytime!

Now when you consider that you can add in Fire Ants or arena to set off the damage trigger to these creatures whenever you want, things become more interesting. Even simpler methods can use whipflare or pyroclasm. Blessing of Leeches enables these cards to become even more powerful, because their default power/toughness was originally meant to limit what they could block and still stay on the field. Leeches eliminates that drawback in a very nice way.

Actually, if you are attacking with it, it's more like a 4/4 with haste (as long the land has been there since upkeep) for . Which, for , is on par. People tend to over look the fact you tap the land these Auras (and the Zendikar ones) are enchanting when attacking, costing you more in the process.

You are also risking a land, but this cycle is a bit more resilient to the ZEN ones as the 1) aren't always a creature, so many field sweepers won't bother them and 2) bounce the aura, not the land, so the 'creature' doesn't die and can be played again.

74428: Akki Blizzard-Herder.author: bif
74428: Akki Blizzard-Herder.text_parsed: Excellent card for Red Deck Wins and Land Destruction type decks.  It forces your opponents to make difficult decisions right from the get-go.  Also note the subtle difference between a card that says "When ~this~ is put in the graveyard, ..." and "Sacrifice ~this~: ..." -- This card stayed good even after the removal of stacked combat damage.  Might have even been playable in Extended if Extended had stayed "big".

74428: Akki Blizzard-Herder.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
74428: Akki Blizzard-Herder.text_parsed:
The akki seemed to have a bit of a land-hate flavour given to them - see this, Akki Avalanchers, Akki Raider and the ever-cool Zo-Zu the Punisher. I wonder if this is intended to reflect something about the actual Japanese akki mythology?

Flavour aside, this is quite similar to Tremble - comparing the two, the upside to this guy is that he could attack for you a couple of times, but the downside is that you might not be able to pop him when you really want to. He makes for an interesting in-block combo with the aforementioned Raider, and while this amounts to an underwhelming +2/+0 ueot in a duel, it could get much stronger in a multiplayer situation.

So, as a fanciful idea of using a relatively unique general, I made an EDH deck with Toshi here.

Holy moly is it way more effective than I thought.

Creatures? No opponents get to have creatures when Toshiro is on the field, and they frequently underestimate him when they first see him. Black mana is abundant with Crypt Ghast (and the Extort is pretty brutal, given all the cheap instants flying around), Nirkana Revenant, and Cabal Coffers. The real trick is including things that profit off kill spells.

Harvester of Souls and Grave Betrayal are both insane, but the real breadwinner is Insidious Dreams. You fill up the graveyard with kill spells you can recast, and you get your pick out of the library.

For indestructible or Hexproof creatures, Grave Pact, Geth's Verdict, edicts, and so on prove invaluable. And if all else fails, Death Cloud. Ogre Slumlord is especially vicious too. It's a relatively budget-friendly EDH deck, given that half of it is just common kill spells.

74436: Shizuko, Caller of Autumn.text_parsed:
Almost every green card (other then weenie elves) that accelerate mana.... always benefit the opponent first... Even this being a legendary creature and turn 3 drop... still rewards your opponent first... Considering this is a turn 3 drop it should really only benefit the caster. I understand something like Magus of the Vineyard, which is a turn 1 drop! So ok... the benefit should be mutual... but by turn 3, so many decks can already be nearing a steady lock if not ending the game... Turn 3 drops should never benefit your opponents. Although within this creature definately lies something that should be rehashed into a newer card with a different twist, or a weaker body but only benefits the caster.

3/5

74441: Blazing Shoal.author: DarthParallax
74441: Blazing Shoal.text_parsed:
banned in Modern?
...

It looks incredibly powerful, I understand the Infect combo...I'm trying to find a way justify keeping this, and banning something else...I don't see it. Yeah, broken in Modern. Which is kind of a shame. This is a really neat card that can be used with plenty of fair strategies. Infect + Red is just asking for trouble, though. I wish the Pros had a bit more soul, and would play only cards that were meant to be played together, rather than ruining deck designer's dreams with fast combos.

I'm an insane Johnny, I understand the appeal of combos, and going infinite, and breaking things in half- but I prefer the convoluted kind that rarely ever work, and therefore provide extra "What. the. ***. ?!!?" value to the moment when you win. The fast combos are boring.

At the risk of losing stars, if it looks like something out of the Yu-Gi-Oh! show (I know, I know....but that cartoon made it fun to watch card games. For me anyway. I loved that show. Particularly the Slifer infinite cards combo- that was my favorite episode ever), then that's a 'legit' combo. If it looks....well, like a Magic ProTour report...I'm sorry, I think it might be the difference in how young you are at heart. Children and the young at heart can be trusted with wacky zany mindblowing combos. People who take the world too seriously cannot.

74441: Blazing Shoal.author: blurrymadness
74441: Blazing Shoal.text_parsed:
Blasphemous Act, Greater Gargadon, and Chancellor of the Forge all work *really* well with this (because they're usable whether this is in hand or not.)

Also, consider using it next to something like Boom//Bust, where one half of the card is playable early game if you need it, but the other half has a big CMC. This counts *total* CMC btw, which means you actually get +8 for that card. Same with Rough//Tumble. Slice and Dice fits here as well.

Everything here is 2 mana or less to use but give between +7 and +10; making the deck easy to assemble and use even with, say, 18 lands.

74441: Blazing Shoal.author: sweetgab
74441: Blazing Shoal.text_parsed:
@Fictionarius: Contrary to what you think, it's pretty obvious Dark Depths is the problematic one. That's why it is the one banned in Modern, not Vampire Hexmage. A card like Dark Depths could either see no play at all or be a part of a broken combo, there is no middle ground. The Hexmage is a much more reasonable card; as if this even needs to be said.

As for infect, I think they made the mistake of not costing it as if it was double strike, because in decks that try to kill as fast as possible, it is basically double strike. Fencing Ace is a 1-power double strike that costs two. That's why Glistener Elf should not have costed one, and Blighted Agent probably should have been somewhat less powerful at two, if not gotten moved to three. 1/1 double strike for one is just not fair.

74441: Blazing Shoal.author: BlakeHN
74441: Blazing Shoal.text_parsed:
Turn 1 combo:
Step 1: Play Mountain.
Step 2: Tap for Goblin Guide, Lighning Serpent, or Spark Elemental.
Step 3: Discard a red card with cc 8 or more for Blazing Shoal.
Step 4: Attack.
Step 5: Discard 2 red cards for Fury of the Horde.
Step 6: Attack again.
Step 7: Win.

7 cards = 20-22 damage on turn 1.
Chances of this happening in an average game = not likely.

74445: Kira, Great Glass-Spinner.author: Selez
74445: Kira, Great Glass-Spinner.text_parsed: Semi-shroud!! This may be even more fun than actual shroud, since it presents your opponents with a very annoying question: should I waste two removal spells on one creature? The obvious answer being yes, since the other creatures are protected also. I'd say you should also play Vines of Vastwood with this card. Your opponent plays one removal spell, countered. The glass shield is down, so you can target Kira now too. Then they play another, and you respond with a Vines of Vastwood, kicked or unkicked. Meh heh heh heh!! And if they have another removal spell so what, they just used three cards to remove ONE creature. Kira, one of the best, most fun card designs ever. 5 outta 5.

I was looking to make a mono blue control EDH and after reading up on some creatures, Kira was just way to good to pass up. Yeah, opponents can target me making me sac things (like Diabolic Tutor), but for the most part Kira, keeps your stuff safe, however there is a drawback. The ability will counter anything you try to do to creatures as well.

Since my deck is somewhat instant/sorcery heavy (what blue deck wouldn't be), I decided to run Runechanter's Pike. The other day I targeted Kira with the Pike, and it gets countered the first time, I equipped it again and it stayed, this however allowed my opponent to tap Kira before my attack phase. That bought him a turn, but it's something I was well aware could happen, and it was worth the risk.

He was playing a mono white Lin-Sivvi rebel EDH, his lack of flying is what did him in, that and the 4 Frost Titans I managed to doppleganger into play keeping everything tapped.

74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.author: BelloAbril
74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.text_parsed: You guys dont see this card's potential. Keiga has a totally diferent role on a deck (anyway its simply awesome for blue decks) , not one this card is meant to fulfill. Personally, it has more of that 'blue taste' AND only costs one blue mana so its easily splashed. It gives you exactly what you need at no cost, it doesnt even have to tap. Plus the hability triggers with 'draw a card' effects, not only your draw phase. It's very good and you simply couldnt ask more thoughness on a blue card with this kind of 'walking tutor' potential. This is late game oriented and can guarantee your last combo piece or stop those annoying land draws when you just need your finisher. 4.5/5.

74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.author: OpeeFomenom
74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.text_parsed:
@allmighty_abacus:
Ponder doesn't interact with draw spells in the way Tomorrow does. There are uses for Ponder that Tomorrow can't do, being that you can ponder on turn one. But Ponder doesn't stop you from losing the game when you run out of cards in your deck, it doesn't give you a pretty nice 1/5 blocker, It doesn't make you immune to effects that try to hurt you when you draw, it doesn't make your extra draw effects more potent and it doesn't have an effect that can be reused without multiple copies or graveyard reshufflings.

74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.author: scumbling1
74447: Tomorrow, Azami's Familiar.text_parsed:
This card would have been so much better with reduced stats and a lower mana cost. Paying six for a slow card-filtering engine is going to have it coming down much too late to make a difference in the game. You'll have had so much time to see a selection of card with your normal draw step that the ability is much less relevant at that point.

At six mana--and at a time when Kamigawa is relegated to only Eternal and casual formats--it's hard not to compare this unfavorably with Consecrated Sphinx and Arcanis the Omnipotent.

74448: Higure, the Still Wind.text_parsed: Ninja are too expensive of a creature type to build a real tribal deck around them. The fact that there are only two real ninja (not talking about changelings here,) in the game that can survive a lightning bolt to the face, and both are legendary and won't be out until turn 4 or 5 at the earliest, means that regardless of what you put in your deck, it's not going to be strong enough to be anything more than a crippled pseudo-tribe deck.

74448: Higure, the Still Wind.author: Enchantment_Removal
74448: Higure, the Still Wind.text_parsed:
This dude (with the other ninjas) is why I started playing Magic. My interactions with this game ever since has been to win with the way cooler strategies (like this here ninjutsu) that tend to be handicapped compared to other themes that the game comes out with. I tend to shy away from things that I hear literally everyone else talking about. Then I wander off to some other strategy which makes it harder for me to win a game. Oh, well. I play Magic mostly for an identity (as stupid as that sounds). Killing someone with faeries and vampires just for the sake of it is kind of... blah, in my opinion.

Bear in mind, all, that ninjutsu is an activated ability so it can be played at instant speed. Ninjutsu can happen anytime in the combat phase after blockers are declared (see the rulings about unblocked attacking creatures on Curtain of Light). If you have a ninja in your hand and it's ninjutsu mana open, you can rescue your unblocked creatures from targeted removal. This (kind of like the forecast mechanic) is not really a gut-busting strategy but still very good to know about in certain situations.

Higure's combat damage ability is almost as important as the unblockable ability. It insures that in one or two turns you will have a mistblade and/or Okiba-gang (or whoever else) to harass your opponent in addition to your regular card draw for the turn. Also, I would say that a good ninja deck should not have a lot of ninjas in it.

74458: Teardrop Kami.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
74458: Teardrop Kami.text_parsed:
@All the "strictly better" addicts out there:
No, "strictly better" means "better in all situations. If you look up "strictly" in any dictionary, you'll see it means something among the lines of "completely", "absolutely", or "conforming completely on an established rule , no matter what the situation".
Therefore, for a card to be "strictly better" than another it has to be better in every possible situation inside the game. This is NOT strictly better than Wandering Ones, because of the Petroglyphs. Maybe you could say it's stricly better than W. Ones inside Kamigawa block, but I doubt even that much.

Oh yeah, back to commenting the card. I suppose it's 1-drop for control, and it's job is just sitting there and then later delaying a big creature's attack. Also has the added bonus of being a spirit (some tribal support and specially the Soulshift mechanic.

74458: Teardrop Kami.author: Noyan_Dar

@Lash_Of_Dragonbreath:
According to MTGSalvation, "Strictly better is a term used to compare cards that are identical in most regards, and in each way they are different the same one is more favorable."
It's slang, like "kosher as christmas," an idiomatic construct that caught on before anyone really caught on.
One could go mad trying to ascertain the better of two similar cards, as a Muraganda Petroglyph'd Wandering ones is made eligible for Meekstoneage, but then it can resist the call of a siren, which brings us back to the Teardrop Kami...

74461: Child of Thorns.author: TopRomen
74461: Child of Thorns.text_parsed:
Situationaly, this can be better than other highly comparable cards like Mogg Fanatic and Fume Spitter.

Mogg Fanatic:
Can help you get that extra point in combat to finish off an enemy creature.
Can help you deal an extra point of damage to the enemy player.
Does not help protect your creature from dying in combat (unless yours has first strike, or the enemy creature has only 1 toughness).
Does not help protect an important creature outside of combat.
Can help by being used to ping off small enemy creatures.

Fume Spitter:
Can help you get that extra point of damage in combat to finish off an enemy creature.
Does not help you deal an extra point of damage to the enemy player.
Can help protect your creature from dying in combat (because the enemy creature also receives decreased power, as well as toughness).
Does not help protect an important creature outside of combat.
Can help by being used to ping off small enemy creatures.

Child of Thorns:
Can help you get that extra point of damage in combat to finish off an enemy creature.
Can help you deal an extra point of damage to the enemy player (in a limited but very flavor-fully green way!).
Can help protect your creature from dying in combat.
Can help protect an important creature outside of combat.
Does not help by being used to ping off small enemy creatures.


If I could make this into a chart, I would. Personally, I think this is a rather solid one drop. I think he deserves somewhere between 3.5 and 4 stars.

On one hand the targeting is so specific that it's rather unwieldy. On the other hand, you're paying 2 mana to destroy something that likely cost far more than that to summon. Of course on a third hand, Legendary cards tend to have at least one form of defense... Antiblack, Shroud, Indestructibility, many of which could just as easily prevent this from happening. A change of wording would do this a lot of good, such as calling it a 'sacrifice' or at least preventing Regen as was stated earlier. It's a tough call.

74465: Hero's Demise.author: DarthParallax
74465: Hero's Demise.text_parsed:
The perfect way to fix this card:

Exile target legendary creature.

The points raised above about how Legendary creatures tend to have protection from Doom-Blade effects effects is sound. I think if Wizards had the chance to ret-con some of their old cards, they would happily adopt this change. Even with this change, it would not be able to stop all the Legendary creatures, and Lightning Greaves would still exist for the rest of them.

Maybe change the casting cost to 1BB. Since anytime the word 'legendary' actually appears in rules text, it's going to be a card that is used primarily for EDH, the extra mana is not a terrible price to pay, and it would be less aggressively hateful against the lower-costing Generals.

Kryptnyt- Be reasonable. Doom Blade and Go for the Throat actually have pretty cool arts/texts. But this one is rather epic-looking, I'll admit. Looks like it came straight out of a major summer superhero movie. :)

74475: Goryo's Vengeance.author: Gelzo
74475: Goryo's Vengeance.text_parsed:
Looks like there's some confusion with the EDH rules, so I'll try to help out.

Rule #12 on the EDH site says, "If a Commander would be put into a graveyard or exile from anywhere, its owner may choose to move it to the command zone instead."

What this means for this card is that if you have it in your hand or are hoping to have it, you can let your commander go to the graveyard instead before you cast this.

So, for a card and two mana, you can squeeze an extra attack or tap ability out of your commander. In some decks, I imagine that's easily worth the price. (Also, since it's an instant, I guess you could use it for blocking.)

Just be careful though. If it gets countered, your commander is going to stay in the graveyard until something changes that, and it's not normal in EDH to let your commander go to the graveyard, so your opponents are likely to suspect something if it does.

74475: Goryo's Vengeance.author: Mode
74475: Goryo's Vengeance.text_parsed:
This card has multiple nice advantages:
1) Splice on Arcane, so you can make use of it multiple times (splice always works nicely with Shoals)
2) the fact that it's an instant.
2a) Reanimator spells normally are all sorcery-speed. This one can be played in response to triggers that would make you shuffle the card into your library when they're put into a graveyard.
Which means: Emrakul, the Aeons Torn can kick some serious ass with this card.
2b) You cast this on your opponent's turn for a nice surprise.
3) it can be useful in EDH/Commander. As Gelzo said though, be careful with counterspells.
Other good choices besides Emrakul include:
(within the block:)
- Kokusho, the Evening Star (5/5 flyer and a huge drain effect upon death)
- Iname as One (generally far worse choice from the block, 8/8 without evasion and his cip won't work. But his death returns a spirit permanently)
- Patron of the Moon (5/4 flyer and can get lands into play if you have mana open)
. Patron of the Orochi (8/8 and can untap your green creatures and forstests before attacking. Useful outside of block-constructed with BG dual lands: Bayou, Overgrown Tomb)
- Sekki, Seasons' Guide (not useful by itself, but a win-con with Pandemonium, which also synergizes with other creatures you reanimate)

outside of Kamigawa:
- Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre (when cast early even better than Progenitus because of the Vindicate-trigger)
- Bladewing the Risen (4/4 flyer and returns a dragon)
- Nicol Bolas (after emrakul likely the most powerful choice when Goryo's Vengeance is cast early: if you hit with this 7/7 flyer your opponent's hand is gone.)
- Progenitus (hitting for 10 damage that your opponent will most likely be unable to stop makes this a good choice in any part of the game.
- Elesh Norn (4/7 and provides a one-sided +2/+2 and -2/-2)
- Karador, Ghost Chieftain (3/4 and allows hardcasting a creature from the graveyard)
- Tariel, Reckoner of Souls (4/7 flyer that can reanimate a random creature from your opponent's graveyard)
- Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter (5/5 lifelinked flyer that gives you a sac outlet and with that the ability to pump him or torture your opponent's creatures)
- Phage the Untouchable (... hurr.)

If you run white, you can use Angelic Renewal to keep your fattie permanently (Saffi Eriksdotter also works if you add green, which could get a bit tricky. Second Sunrise works as well, but that one's not worth it unless you add more synergies for it maybe, since you'll have to cast it the turn you cast Goryo's Vengeance)

74475: Goryo's Vengeance.author: DeaTh-ShiNoBi
74475: Goryo's Vengeance.text_parsed:
Progenitus is not actually a valid target for this card. Progenitus' graveyard recycle works different than the legendary Eldrazi's graveyard recycling effects. If you read Emrakul, the Aeons Torn's effect, it reads:

"When Emrakul is put into a graveyard from anywhere, its owner shuffles his or her graveyard into his or her library."

Thus, he is in the graveyard when his trigger activates, and can be responded to via Goryo's Vengeance. Progenitus' effect on the other hand, reads:

"If Progenitus would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, reveal Progenitus and shuffle it into its owner's library instead."

Note the important word here: "instead". Instead of being put into the Graveyard, Progenitus is shuffled into the Library. At no point in the game is it ever possible for Progenitus to be in the Graveyard, for even a second.


Unrelated, some people seem to be misunderstanding the rules regarding the end of turn for this card. It exiles the card it revives at the end of turn, so no "upon death" effects activate. Sorry, but Kokusho, the Evening Star does not combo with this card unless you can get him killed before the end of turn (such as sacrificing him). Same for Saffi Eriksdotter.
74475: Goryo's Vengeance.text_posted:
[autocard]Progenitus[/autocard] is not actually a valid target for this card.  Progenitus' graveyard recycle works different than the legendary Eldrazi's graveyard recycling effects.  If you read [autocard]Emrakul, the Aeons Torn[/autocard]'s effect, it reads:

"When Emrakul [b]is[/b] put into a graveyard from anywhere, its owner shuffles his or her graveyard into his or her library."

Thus, he is in the graveyard when his trigger activates, and can be responded to via Goryo's Vengeance.  Progenitus' effect on the other hand, reads:

"If Progenitus [b]would[/b] be put into a graveyard from anywhere, reveal Progenitus and shuffle it into its owner's library [b]instead[/b]."

Note the important word here: "instead".  Instead of being put into the Graveyard, Progenitus is shuffled into the Library.  At no point in the game is it ever possible for Progenitus to be in the Graveyard, for even a second.


Unrelated, some people seem to be misunderstanding the rules regarding the end of turn for this card.  It [b]exiles[/b] the card it revives at the end of turn, so no "upon death" effects activate.  Sorry, but [autocard]Kokusho, the Evening Star[/autocard] does not combo with this card unless you can get him killed before the end of turn (such as sacrificing him).  Same for [autocard]Saffi Eriksdotter[/autocard].

74480: Crack the Earth.text_parsed:
Fun card. Works great with the splice cards, as well as cards like Act of Treason. Yes please, I'll take control of your Darksteel Colossus, bash you in the face with it, and then get rid of it altogether.

It's also a fun reset button. Say your opponent goes first, and sacs his Polluted Delta to fetch his Watery Grave and plays it untapped to play a Ponder. Play your mountain and then this card. Sure, his library is a bit more organized, but he's down 3 life and a duel land.

74480: Crack the Earth.author: ScissorsLizard
74480: Crack the Earth.text_parsed:
@blurrymadness: 'comboing' this with ball lightning basically just means you devote a card in your deck towards making your opponent sacrifice the permanent they need the least on turn 4+... assuming ball lightning survives combat. That effect just isn't worth a spot in a deck.

Busting lands at the beginning of the game seems better, but that's a game of luck. If they're manascrewed, great. You win. If they're not, you probably won't be able to keep on top of them every turn, and they'll build up lands eventually. In order to ensure that you can destroy their lands early game, you'd have to stack your deck with Raze type cards, which suggests that your deck probably won't be able to do much else.

74480: Crack the Earth.author: SAUS3
74480: Crack the Earth.text_parsed:
Such a cool name and such an amazingly powerful - if suicidal - effect. This is like a red smallpox. I love it.

There are a few places where this really works. For me, it is when you have a non-land permanent you don't care about (say a weak goblin or something) and a powerful creature you intend on winning with (like adamaro for instance), while an opponent has a non-land permanent that is really annoying you (perhaps a creature that is too strong to kill or will thwart your plan like Damia for instance).

You tap for 5 mana, cast thoughts of ruin and then cast this when there are no lands left.

It ADDS to land destruction - it doesn't do it well by itself, and taking out a land will often not even be worth it since you will be losing 2 cards to get 1. You cast it the turn after you blew up all the lands so that again, everyone is at 0 mana, or you cast it when there are no lands to sacrifice (on your opponent's side) so they have to sacrifice something important.

I'm going to put it in my Adamaro EDH deck because keeping people off mana is extremely important to the game plan and this is an extremely powerful effect for 1 mana.

74487: Tendo Ice Bridge.author: Mode
74487: Tendo Ice Bridge.text_parsed:
I don't know why so many of you compare it to Gemstone Mine. Those are for different uses.
Tendo Ice Bridge is not necessarily for such color-heavy decks as Gemstone Mine is.
The Mine gives you any mana for three turns, and you're done.
This one has a permanent colorless mana ramp, and provides a single use of any color that you should use wisely.

I'm surprised it uses simple charge counters. Then again, you'll notice there are only a few cases where you can actually place charge counters on lands instead of artifacts.
This could still be useful in a three-color profilerate deck though.

And the art is gorgeous.
(That is one beast of a bridge if this little piece of land can produce as much mana as the mountains left and right from it :D)

74493: Split-Tail Miko.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
74493: Split-Tail Miko.text_parsed:
I think we're pretty much guaranteed to return to Kamigawa eventually. The revisits to Mirrodin and Ravnica were super popular, and I think very well done. They even teased us with Tamiyo, the Moon Sage. Revisits in general and probably Kamigawa in particular are very much a part of Magic's plan for the future.

And we do need to get more bite in fox tribal. Every fox seems flavorful but a little underwhelming. And we only have two non-Kamigawa foxes, Ice Age's Arctic Foxes and Innistrad's Silverchase Fox.

Edit: Well, come to find out Kamigawa scored very low mechanically and creatively in market research, and even Tamiyo-chan was received poorly. Most people that like Kamigawa didn't actually play it in standard and limited, like me. A return is less likely than I thought. Maro said they might do it, but only if they can find some compelling way to make it exciting.

But think of the poor foxes... maybe like Saikuba said we could get a Reynard expy from Lorwyn?

74500: Quash.author: ultratog1028
74500: Quash.text_parsed:
awesome story. back around ravnica block, my casual group had a player who had the most annoying boros deck ever. he won using boros fury-shield almost everytime. everyone hated it. as in "tear-this-card-up-I-never-want-to-see-it-again" hate.

anyway i was playing a two-headed giant game against his boros deck and a saproling deck. i was playing a mono blue control deck that was 80% counters and bounce just to *** others off. my ally was playing izzet control. we had totally locked down the field and by ally swung with a Wee Dragonauts that was like a 13/3. in response boros-man windmill swung down his first Boros fury-shield and yelled "Boros fury-shield!!!!!", thinking he had just won (we were at, i believe, 15 and he had a shock in hand).

my response? Windmill slam Quash.
his response? "Huh? (he reads the card) F***!"

he took the shields out of his deck shortly after.

74500: Quash.text_posted:

74500: Quash.author: GrimjawxRULES
74500: Quash.text_parsed:
@Minus_Prime: Aegisofthunder is referring to the part of the card that causes you to search and exile the remaining copies of Banefire. Read the rulings:
"If the spell is not countered (because the spell it targets can't be countered), then it does not get exiled but all the other copies in the graveyard, hand, and library are exiled."

He may not counter the Banefire being cast, but the opponent won't have other copies left in their deck.

@Ultratog1028: I know how you feel about Boros Fury-Shield ... One of my friends used to have it in a boros deck too - I remember attacking ftw with a 13/10 flying Primeval Force (I had a flipped Homura), only to lose when he cast the Shield ...

Back to the card: Quash is an awesome spell if you know what you're dealing with, though it makes me sad that it is limited to Instants and Sorceries. If you're running a casual counter deck, you should probably have 1 or 2 in your deck depending on your tastes. It's always nice to exile all Lightning Bolts or Doom Blades from your opponent's deck.

74500: Quash.author: Minus_Prime
74500: Quash.text_parsed: Edit: Der, sorry. I thought AgesofThunder was referring specifically to the spell on the stack. Yes, it will exile the other copies, which... usually doesn't matter with a game-ender like Banefire. 5 stars for Grimja.
74500: Quash.text_posted: Edit: Der, sorry. I thought AgesofThunder was referring specifically to the spell on the stack. Yes, it will exile the other copies, which... usually doesn't matter with a game-ender like [autocard]Banefire[/autocard]. 5 stars for Grimja.

74500: Quash.author: Ferlord
74500: Quash.text_parsed:
This is a very good counter card, and can arguably be more effective than Counterspell in some situations

Let's say your opponent has a Red Agro deck. Are you going to play Counterspell on that Lightning Bolt? Probably not, because it just costs 1 CMC (but you may because it still deals 3 damage, but that's not my point). Now, if you played Quash on that, then they will lose one of their best burn cards.

I originally thought it simply countered any spell, but still, it can make something like Dark Ritual or Harrow useless for 4 CMC.

4.5/5

74500: Quash.author: LordRandomness

I really wish there was a way to hit an uncounterable spell with this, then hit the spell with Venser, Shaper Savant such that it's in your opponent's hand when you search there. Alas, it'll either be countered because the target disappeared or Quash will be done resolving by the time you can drop Venser.

BUT! If there are two copies of the same uncounterable spell on the stack, that's a different matter. (This might seem stupidly narrow, but hitting a Reverberated Banefire with this after bouncing the original? Pretty funny.)

74500: Quash.author: leomistico
74500: Quash.text_parsed:
Not that this one is bad, but I prefer the old art...
One of my favourite counterspell, just because I countered once a freshly casted Incinerate, removing all 4, slowing down the burn. So satisfying! It's nice, interesting counter to eliminate all instance of annoying spells like Life from the Loam, Deep Analysis, etc... But, unlike the other cards of this cycle, this one doesn't exile directly the card that it's targeting, so doesn't counter a uncounterable spell. The other ones can exile indestructible permanents...
It's a pity that isn't really effective in EDH, because I love Lobotomy effects, so I'd play for sure!
4.5/5

"Open fist." So, like... a hand?

Also, trivia: He is the 'good' counterpart to the evil Jerrard of the Closed Fist.

74507: Iwamori of the Open Fist.author: Ninjitsu
74507: Iwamori of the Open Fist.text_parsed:
For everyone who's dissing his secondary effect, think of it like this.
They always ask Bruce Wayne, whether its the criminals who bring out the Batman, or the Batman who attracts the criminals.

In the same sense, Iwamori is such a strong fighter, he attracts foes to himself! I think Wizards did a great job translating this flavor to card form.

For more on Iwamori's personal battle, check out http://www.wizards.com/Magic/TCG/Article.aspx?x=magic/bok/iwamori

74507: Iwamori of the Open Fist.author: Elegy
74507: Iwamori of the Open Fist.text_parsed:
Iwamori is one card that would've had fantastic flavor text.
I'm sad that monks didn't get their own keyword. Samurais have Bushido, Ninjas have Ninjutsu, but Monks were a lonely class tribe. A cool one would be sort of like equipment with Living Weapon only instead of a 0/0 Germ you get a 3/3 Monk, already holding the weapon. Or Monks that can use weapons in different ways. This was kind of their only opportunity to capitalize on the effectiveness of martial arts.
Great flavor on Iwamori, he is stronger than a Stampeding Rhino.
Goes in Captain Sisay EDH to fill that role.

74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.author: Calver
74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.text_parsed:
Like Snaxme said, this card was probably designed to be a center piece. Believe it or not R&D sometimes puts out cards that aren't Baneslayers (and subsequently are affordable enough to actually enjoy).

To contribute, I use this guy in my Bazaar Trader deck. If I don't have the mana to kill him off right away, I can still trade him on the stack if my opponent tries to kill him. Either way I get a 1-sided wrath of god for somewhere between 4 and 6 mana (heck, it's better than Wrath since my opponent has to sacrifice: no regen and no indestructibility).

Cast him. Now let Bazaar Trader impose that enchained monstrosity (troll-physics style with twirly hands) on your opponent.

all he needed was flying to make him great. but I also like how no Kamigawa demons (or almost none) have flying. It makes them distinct and interesting :)


if you're wondering about the flavor, it's because he is so powerful he can slay an army of ogres. that's why he's considered dangerous to the point of needing 99 monks to contain.

yes, when you overanalyze it as a card in a game, then you can prove everything is crap and you can prove the game is stupid and all sort of other things I care not to hear about.

He's a Demon Spirit from the Other World. Instead of imagining any of the Kamigawa cards being represented by their mechanics, imagine stripping them of everything except Name, Art, and Flavor Text and then designing a videogame character after them. In this way, Kamigawa is a lot like the set Legends. To do justice to the awesome, you have to think outside the box of being a Magic Player.

This guy would have been a tremendous BAMF on the Jackie Chan Adventures show! :D

He's not particularly devastating on his own, but as a low curve creature, I kind of like the idea of putting him in Kaalia. I am redoing my Kaalia from Scratch, starting from flavor. All 3 Myojins are cool, because they have 'divinity counters'. Kaalia seems like a blasphemous individual who would yoink That Which Was Taken for funses.

I mean I'm also going to put more traditional choices like Bloodgift Demon in it, but think about it like this: Commander has so much recursion from things like Living Death and Liliana Vess and whatnot that even Wrathing yourself with your first creature probably isn't the end of the world. Kaalia seems to have a huge problem finding any creatures strong enough to want to include that you can play before you have your Commander ability active.

I guess what I'm saying is that if you have certain cards that make all creatures you can use them on ridiculous, like Gisela or Sword of War and Peace and if you still put in your copy of Akroma, then...well...I don't see that EVERY creature has to be the biggest and best. getting the curve to work right is important too and I, for one, welcome the fact that he's a low-costing Demon.

74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.author: psychichobo
74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.text_parsed:
Say what you like about Yukora, but in three games so far with my ogre-demon deck he single-handedly saved the day. Oddly, he always seemed to turn up as my only creature, and I just drop an enchantment or two on him whilst swinging like a nutter.
I'm talking about multiplayer here by the way, which explains where all the removal's going, but for some reason he never gets targeted until he's killed a player or ripped way too much of their health off. Then he dies, and my other creatures finally start turning up.

Ah, for the crazy days of beginner's magic....

74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.author: blurrymadness
74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.text_parsed:
I kinda wish he felt more epic. Rakdos is a demon with a huge drawback and huge reward while feeling powerful, epic, flavorful, and being generally avoided by most decks. This guy is missing that nice *HOLY CRAP* feeling.

They should've really upped the ante with something; say.. the Phage ability tacked onto a 5/3 body. Then it just walks up and owns the game or it owns you! To me that's good design because it adds a lot of tension. A 5/5 at a good cost adds a tiny bit of tension, but it's lacking that feeling that makes many Demons so loveable; yet most of the Kamigawa demons unlovable. Where's the epic?

I collect and play demons in so so many decks because of that feeling, the awesome art, etc, but this guy misses all of those marks.. and yet I still have to go buy a couple and stick them somewhere..

74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.author: ParallaxtheRevan
74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.text_parsed:
Although....if it took 99 monks to imprison 1 Yukora, I suppose 4 Phyrexian Obliterators would just flat depopulate the entire plane of Kamigawa? lol

Blightsteel Colossus might even be able to compleat O-Kagachi o.O

EDIT: By the way, there is a SERIOUSLY over-looked comparison I cannot believe I missed: the best way to evaluate a MAGIC card is to try to think of another card with a similar mana cost that could have HIGHLY influenced R&D's thoughts on it-- regardless of if RnD is thinking like Modern Players or not.


Juzam Djinn. BAM. Yukora is the first Demon to be easily castable in any given casual game of Magic since Juzam. Instead of costing a Boatload of mana, He costs a simple Handful.

He costs 4 Mana. 4 mana, it turns out, tends to be the space where a large percent of amazing Creatures, Planeswalkers, and Enchantments come from. In the days of Lorwyn, it was still conventional wisdom that ''5 mana spells ought to win you the game'', meaning that what you do on Turn 4 matters A LOT. A card that costs more, still has to be produced by your deck between Turn 3-5, with ramp, or you have to be stocking extremely powered hateful Control elements.

a 4 mana Rare fatty compares to cards like Juzam Djinn (good), Serra Angel (great but +1 mana), and Hill Giant (bad). I would never play Hill Giant, but I've decided that I love how his existence does end up serving as part of a metric for me. :)

I think comparing Magic Sets from Ice Age to Xth Edition is where to get the best inspiration for 'realistic expectations' from.

I like how Lorwyn pushed its Rares, but those Rares need to be acknowledged as Pushed. I like how the Shards' Ultimatums, and in general its Rares and Mythics are Fantastic because they give you Legends-type casting costs for Legendary Power. Shards cards suffer greatly in power level unless your mana is deliciously smooth, like Ravnica-smooth.
Ravnica itself, both Ravnica blocks, to me show about the limits of how far you can PUSH things before they break (they broke in Shadowmoor, with too many filter lands busting the 5cc deck wide open and making Cruel Ultimatum and Progenitus really normal cards to see in Standard)

Start with Tempest-Xth as your evaluation "Base Point". I slightly dislike the New Core Sets because I no longer feel they actually serve as appropriate "Base Points", and I think I'm forced to conclude that philosophically I don't want CORE sets to HAVE Mythic Rares-- BUT I enjoy them in Blocks! :)

(Exception: if Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker had been the one and only Mythic Rare in M13, that would have actually been even more Fantastic)

Compared to Core Sets 8, 9, and Xth, Yukora, the Prisoner is quite undercosted and I'm tempted to just let him hurt me when he hurts me in exchange for having a 4-mana 5/5. When a 4-mana 5/5 was considered interestingly good, maybe not ''WOWZERS, *THAT* will see Legacy Play :P o.o " but, you know, something I'd like to shuffle up and experiment with? Then the card is very nicely made :D

Time Spiral, Lorwyn, and Shards Blocks were all a period of Power Creeping-- and comparing them back to Xth and before, they don't seem egregious, they just seem "Powerful", without obsoleting a Metric Ton of cards.

Zendikar and Scars Block pretty much destroyed the playability of anything pre-Ravnica that wasn't Degenerate; and/or it made what was previously considered "Pushed" to be "Base Level" for playability.

74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.author: OlvynChuru
74510: Yukora, the Prisoner.text_parsed: I've noticed that not too many people seem to mention the obvious combo with this card: use it with ogres! There are actually quite a few good ogres nowadays. I'd be happy with casting Yukora on turn 4, and then bloodrushing Wrecking Ogre onto it on turn 5 and bonking the opponent for sixteen. Yukora's main advantage over Phyrexian Obliterator is that it is more splashable, which means that Yukora can be used in black-red decks (which can use all the good red ogres).

74512: Ornate Kanzashi.author: Voriki
74512: Ornate Kanzashi.text_parsed: I don't know why people keep saying that this card is too expensive. Sure it costs 5 just to play. But you're also paying 5 in order to: Steal / exile, at most, HALF the opponent's deck (in 1v1), steal lands, play spells of a different color with said stolen lands, and force the opponent to either play more defensively at the worry of losing cards or get rid of the card as soon as they lose something they want. It single-handedly mana-starved a 3 color deck that lost a lot of low cost cards once I got about 2 of their lands. 4/5 in my opinion. We can't always get scared off just becuase a card is expensive, that's what makes us have to be creative.

74512: Ornate Kanzashi.author: EDH-Lives
74512: Ornate Kanzashi.text_parsed:
This card is great in EDH/Commander. I run it in a casual control magic deck focused on stealing other's cards. I can get my opponent's land and play it for more mana, while depriving them of it.

Best though is stealing important/obnoxious artifacts like all the Swords, or Sensei's Divining Top. I don't have my Top in my deck, because I find the card annoying, but I will take my opponent's Top and use it to stack my topdeck. Or if I'm really annoyed by it, simply exile it and don't play it. It is one of the few ways to actually eliminate that card. Did that more than once at games, and everyone but the Top's owner cheered. :)

The other great thing about Ornate Kanzashi, as someone else mentioned, is my opponents have to play very carefully. They don't want to waste a removal spell on it, but they don't want their prizes taken before they even play them.

In a large EDH game, this card is more than worth its mana cost. Especially since I have several ways to untap it in response to other's actions.

74515: Veil of Secrecy.author: MisterAction
74515: Veil of Secrecy.text_parsed:
Such a versatile card. In a ninja deck, it can be a kill spell, a bounce spell, a discard spell, a cantrip, a reanimator, or even a tutoring effect, all with free damage to the opponent. On the opponent's turn, it becomes an Intervene.

Splicing it is a great way to get a ninja back to your hand, but you don't need to be playing arcane for this to be a great card.

74519: Shining Shoal.author: Asmodi0000
74519: Shining Shoal.text_parsed:
This card is amazing. Easily one of my favorite ever printed.

It's so comforting to have it in your hand. It can keep you or your creatures safe from damage, and can kill creatures or even players. But, what makes it awesome is that it's a combat trick that can be used even when you're tapped out, which puts another level onto the game. There's been times I've tapped myself out on purpose while I had a Razia in hand just so I could have my opponent go for an all out assault, thinking he's got the game won, until I redirect the fatal points of damage from myself to his face, either killing him outright or putting him within reach of a burn spell.

It's just so awesome to pull those kind of surprise victories, and this card let's anyone do it almost too easily.

I do wish the art/flavor was a little bit cooler though.

74522: Aura Barbs.author: kiseki
74522: Aura Barbs.text_parsed:
The creature clause is pretty wonky. It isn't going to do much on its own, but the ability to block a creature, and then throw this on top might actually kill something.
Are you expecting them to have at least 3 enchantments out? Then by all means play this card. Enchantments are the whipping boy of card types and in a lot of games this is going to be a lame draw. Any time you wish you had a shock over something like this, you know you are looking at a niche card.
It would be fun to pull of a victory with this, Enchanted evening, and a couple of Urza's Armor effects.

See, red has this problem with Enchantments; it can't kill them easily.
The way red gets rid of enchantress is to kill the player.
This is an easy 8-16 damage against enchantress decks... unless they have Solitary Confinement or some such nonsense, then you're screwed!

74526: Yomiji, Who Bars the Way.author: Mode
74526: Yomiji, Who Bars the Way.text_parsed:
I kinda agree, at this cost this guy won't find much use. You don't really want a big body, there are better option out there, you want his ability. But for seven mana? C'mon, this effect isn't seriously exploitable anywhere, you'll have a hard time building a deck with many legendary permanents that synergizes nicely.

This would be more playable if it returned the cards back to play at the end of turn (possibly for a slight cost), it would make the card even powerful. But like that? No, thanks...

I run this in a deck with the ten dragons from the Planar Chaos set. Any one of them enchanted with Bear Umbra means I can drop up to 2 a turn. And this guy lets me bring them back.
EDIT: He's no longer in the deck. That was in January 2011. Just for fun I started to build a commander deck around him. I changed my mind. Mind you, people don't like seeing infinite combos, so...

74534: Fumiko the Lowblood.author: Danveldo
74534: Fumiko the Lowblood.text_parsed:
A lovely gem of a card, I've fallen in love with Kamigawa as a fairly new magic player, ranks as my top set, for the sheer joy of the art, the backstory and the cards.

Fumiko ranks high on my Kamigawa love stories. This card with any number of mass boosts could be leathal; Hold the Line, Call to Glory (Potentially), Iizuka the Ruthless, Ethereal Haze for an all out tap fest or any other of those Boshido totting Samurai she calls a deck with. And that is not including the already said alternates.

Note I have only mentioned Kamigawa here, if you expand into other sets. You could do alot of interesting mixes here, definatly a 5/5 in my humble opinion

74535: Blademane Baku.text_parsed:
It isn't great, but if you can get a few down in a deck heavy with spirits and/or arcana, and pair it with a field-wide (arcane) sorcery, you can do a large amount of spike damage.

If you play, say, 2 Bakus, another spirit, and an arcane sorcery, you can get a 7/1 and a 5/1 for a turn.

If you can't...they are just crappy 2cc 1/1s.

74542: Patron of the Orochi.author: justicarphaeton

Still, the Snake Offering allows for some interesting shenanigans, especially with untapping all your lands if you're mono-green.   Those sorts of interesting choices seem to go against the 'all upside' cards that Wizards is so fond of, which I personally find a bit disappointing.  Overall, a really neat card.

74546: Eradicate.author: Splizer
74546: Eradicate.text_parsed:
Even though it's wrong to, I'm going to go ahead and comapre this to the new Sever The Bloodline.

Both cost 4CMC, and both exile a creature, although Sever the Bloodline is less colour intensive and is not restricted to nonblack creatures.

Eradicate has a taped-on Surgical Extraction effect, while Sever The Bloodline employs a watered-down Maelstrom Pulse quality. Eradicate thus can rip strategies apart, while Sever The bloodline can wreck someone's board position, so they employ two dIfferent ways of awesome.

Eradicate is an UNCOMMON (Blimey!), but Sever the Bloodline does have Flashback; it can exile at least two creatures that threaten your board with its use...

AAAGGHHH bugger, they both win! It really depends if you wish to establish board dominance or just want to rip a combo to bits, but let's use them BOTH!!!

74546: Eradicate.author: JaxsonBateman
74546: Eradicate.text_parsed:
"So I hear you like wincons?" ^^

That's the strength of this card. Most decks include a 3 or 4-of of a fantastic creature as a wincon. Eradicate, and you're not only removing a big threat from the field, but you're also sucking wincons right out of their deck. If this thing were around when GR Valakut ramp was stomping all over standard (thanks mainly to Primeval Titan), I would have been very surprised if it didn't at least see sideboard spots.

74546: Eradicate.author: OlvynChuru
74546: Eradicate.text_parsed:
Eradicate is really funny in casual when you and your opponent don't know each other's decks very well.

Player 1 casts Mirror Entity

Player 2 exclaims, "Ugh, ANOTHER Mirror Entity?! How many of those do you HAVE in the deck?!"

Player 1 says, "I have four of them in the deck. Yes, that's right."

Player 2 plays Eradicate on the Mirror Entity.

Player 1 does a facepalm.

74552: Kyoki, Sanity's Eclipse.author: Trygon_Predator
74552: Kyoki, Sanity's Eclipse.text_parsed: Kamigawa keeps turning up surprising cards! This one just screams to be built around. I wouldn't mind a Spirit/Arcane Commander deck with Kyoki at the helm, and packed with discard effects - Kamigawa alone turns up nasties like Myojin of Night's Reach and Infernal Kirin, the latter of which synergizes well with Kyoki's spiritcraft. True, he's a legendary Craw Wurm, but it's that ability that puts the pressure on your opponents, especially once they start exiling good stuff. Cons: you will instantly become the bad guy when you summon Kyoki. But it's targeted, so you could slow down the one player who's ahead.

74552: Kyoki, Sanity's Eclipse.author: Phelplan
74552: Kyoki, Sanity's Eclipse.text_parsed:
I really want to like this card because the exile effect is great. The only problem is that it hits the table so late in the game and discard decks are most effective when the game is still fresh and new (when people still have a hand full of cards). I just pulled this from an old pack of Betrayers and I want to build around it just for fun but I think I will have to go reanimator if I want decent results.

If I could redesign this card, I would make him casting cost with a 4/3 body so you could dark ritual him out but not without risk.

74555: Mirror Gallery.author: divine_exodus
74555: Mirror Gallery.text_parsed:
@MasterOfEtherium:

The legendary rule was made to prevent you from putting in tons of really good creatures. Imagine 2 Emrakuls in play. It just isn't fair. Magic was not intended (unfortunately) to be a 4-5 turn game. The legend rule is just one way to make the game more fair and slow it down. It's like the "four card" rule. You can't have, say, 15 black lotuses in one deck. If no one in your group plays with the legend rule, you are barely even playing magic. It's just like saying, "Hey Guys Hand Size Stupid Lets All Draw 45 Cards LOL Rawr".

You can't just keep changing the rules, buddy. Find cards that change them for you.

74555: Mirror Gallery.author: xwayj
74555: Mirror Gallery.text_parsed:
Am I the only one that hates the wording on this card? I think it should say what it does rather than refer to a rule. (So: "Multiple legendary permanents with the same name may be on the battlefield at the same time", or something like that.)

Even though everyone that knows about the legend rule (that is, everyone who isn't very new to the game) will get what it does, I still think it should be written out on the card (or rather, in the oracle text) instead of referring to the rulebook.

It's kind of like if Laboratory Maniac would say "Rule 104.3c causes you to win the game instead of losing it." (If you don't have a rulebook nearby: Rule 104.3c is the rule that makes you lose when you need to draw from an empty library.)
