74555: Mirror Gallery.author: BongRipper420
74555: Mirror Gallery.text_parsed:
As awesome as this card is, it really feels boarder line unusable as a 5 drop. Yeah, it enables some cool combos and all, but you're paying 5 mana for a card that doesn't do anything on it's own. Also, even if one managed to use this correctly, it would suck pretty hard to have this removed at just the wrong time.

That being said, I'm sure if you build around it, it can be devastating, and I can think of many legends whom become absolutely ridiculous with multiples ( Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary, any of the Praetors, ect). Still though, it's very difficult to use this card effectively. So much so that I've never really seen it used. Would it have been so bad to lower the cost to or so?

Also, broken with Gaea's Cradle

3.5/5, mostly for the potential.

74568: Uproot.author: Enelysios
74568: Uproot.text_parsed:
Strictly worse, as the magic developers use it, doesn't mean always worse really because you can always find some exception. The fact that Liquify exists doesn't make this card not strictly worse than Fallow Earth.

I am reluctant to call this strictly worse though because arcane decks are a thing that actually exist and those would be okay paying the extra mana to be able to splice onto this and get the bonuses for arcane spells many cards provide in Kamigawa. Sadly splice was a nasty degenerate mechanic with no support outside of block or this could be a more legitimate alternative.

74572: Heartless Hidetsugu.author: Wizard-of-the-Toast
74572: Heartless Hidetsugu.text_parsed:
Furnace of Rath doesn't always give an instant tie, due to the words "rounded down" on this card. Instead Heartless Hidestugu would reduce all players life totals to 1 or zero depending on whether their life total is odd or even respectively. I think this is much better. All you need to is make sure your's is odd and theirs is even, but this does involve life gain/loss as it's impossible to cause an odd numbered amount of damage with the Furnace in play. My other favourite combos:
Lifelink on Hidestugu.
Grafted Exoskeleton (especially vs lifegain decks)
Pariah's Shield preferably on Stuffy Doll (auto win if your life total is higher than your opponent's, or autowin if you also have the Furnace of Rath out)

74572: Heartless Hidetsugu.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
74572: Heartless Hidetsugu.text_parsed:
I just puzzled out a ridiculously unlikely first-turn kill with this guy. It's not tournament-legal, since it needs multiple instances of two restricted vintage cards, but it also does not use the Power 9.

First turn, opening hand: Mountain, 4 Lotus Petals, Seething Song, Wheel of Fortune.
Play Mountain, all four Petals, tap Mountain, sac two Petals, cast Seething Song, cast Wheel of Fortune. Discard nothing but draw 7!

Draw: Healing Salve, 3 Seething Songs, Simian Spirit Guide, Mass Hysteria, Wheel of Fortune.

You still have in the pool. Sac a Petal for , play Healing Salve, gain 3 Life. Sac last Petal for , use all mana to cast Seething Song, then cast the two other Seething Songs. You have in the pool. Toss the Spirit Guide, use to cast Mass Hysteria, use to cast Wheel of Fortune, hand was empty again, draw another 7. You still have in the pool.

Draw: Heartless Hidetsugu, either Overblaze or Furnace of Rath, and three further Spirit Guides, these can even be Elvish Spirit Guides, and two more cards of no import.

Toss all three Spirit Guides, giving you six and an additional three mana ( or , does not matter). Play Hidetsugu, and either play Furnace, or target him with Overblaze. He has Haste thanks to Mass Hysteria.

Tap him, he deals double damage, hitting your opponent for 20... and you only for 22 of your 23.

Opponent dead, you have a Near-Death Experience but win and enter the annals of Magic history. :P
74572: Heartless Hidetsugu.text_posted:
I just puzzled out a ridiculously unlikely first-turn kill with this guy. It's not tournament-legal, since it needs multiple instances of two restricted vintage cards, but it also does not use the Power 9.

First turn, opening hand: Mountain, 4 [autocard]Lotus Petal[/autocard]s, [autocard]Seething Song[/autocard], [autocard]Wheel of Fortune[/autocard].
Play Mountain, all four Petals, tap Mountain, sac two Petals, cast Seething Song, cast Wheel of Fortune. Discard nothing but draw 7!

Draw: [autocard]Healing Salve[/autocard], 3 Seething Songs, [autocard]Simian Spirit Guide[/autocard], [autocard]Mass Hysteria[/autocard], Wheel of Fortune.

You still have [R][R] in the pool. Sac a Petal for [W], play Healing Salve, gain 3 Life. Sac last Petal for [R], use all mana to cast Seething Song, then cast the two other Seething Songs. You have [R][R][R][R][R][R][R][R][R] in the pool. Toss the Spirit Guide, use [R] to cast Mass Hysteria, use [R][R][R] to cast Wheel of Fortune, hand was empty again, draw another 7. You still have [R][R][R][R][R][R] in the pool.

Draw: Heartless Hidetsugu, either [autocard]Overblaze[/autocard] or [autocard]Furnace of Rath[/autocard], and three further Spirit Guides, these can even be [autocard]Elvish Spirit Guide[/autocard]s, and two more cards of no import.

Toss all three Spirit Guides, giving you six [R] and an additional three mana ([R] or [G], does not matter). Play Hidetsugu, and either play Furnace, or target him with Overblaze. He has Haste thanks to Mass Hysteria.

Tap him, he deals double damage, hitting your opponent for 20... and you only for 22 of your 23.

Opponent dead, you have a [autocard]Near-Death Experience[/autocard] but win and enter the annals of Magic history. :P

74573: Kumano's Blessing.author: OmegaSerris
74573: Kumano's Blessing.text_parsed:
I think it was the flash that did this card in. See Ophidian Eye vs Curiosity. It probably would have had either some sort of pump or been around in cost without it.

It's funny to see WotC's nervousness about combat tricks show up in the form of cards like these. This ability it almost 9 times out of 10 completely insignificant to your opponent. Sure, there are some specific cases where it's needed to prevent recurrence, but I know for a fact this wasn't the first block either effect was introduced in. They can't say they were testing the waters with it or some other excuse.

They should have added something else to this to make it not such a dead draw in those 9 other cases and a pretty bad 2 for 1 in the chance it would have helped but the creature gets zapped. Even a cantrip when you played it wouldn't have hurt it's cause.

74580: Harbinger of Spring.author: OlvynChuru
74580: Harbinger of Spring.text_parsed:
Guys, this is better than it looks. Its one toughness doesn't really matter since most creatures won't even be able to deal damage to it. If you bolt it, sure, whatever, I guess I'll just bring back my Crib Swap.

What is important to remember is, CMC to power and toughness ratios are not everything. Clearly, if all that matters is that ratio, then Phytohydra is worse than Face of Fear.

3.8/5

EDIT: I just realized that the token that Crib Swap gives counts as a spirit, which means that it can block and kill this. I guess it's not THAT good.

3.1/5

I had a deck that I had put little unblockable guys into in order to better hit folks with ninjas, but I found it to be unwieldy and I often didn't have enough mana to cast what I wanted to cast after the ninjas had hit. Ornithopter gets around a lot of those problems by costing , and it has evasion!

If you haven't tried NinjasRidingOrnithopters.dec, you should really give it a try. I was pleasantly surprised, and now I will swear by it.

74587: Ninja of the Deep Hours.author: Ladon---
74587: Ninja of the Deep Hours.text_parsed:
Actually channelblaze, you are correct, he can be ninjutsu'd in after combat damage. Look at the official rulings on Higure, the Still Wind for more information.

@littlebeast
According to the rulings, yes you can. A neat little trick I've enjoyed doing is to give my preferred Ninja first strike, deal first strike combat damage, ninjutsu him out with a cheap ninja like Mistblade Shinobi or Skullsnatcher, then ninjutsu the Ninja I just took out back in, right on time for regular combat damage. In the case of Ninja of the Deep Hours, assuming he's holding a No-Dachi (and there's no Ronin Warclub in play), that trick will give you six damage and two cards for 1UU.

74587: Ninja of the Deep Hours.author: MrFluffyThing
74587: Ninja of the Deep Hours.text_parsed:
@Ladon

You can only activate Ninjutsu after First strike damage is dealt if there's a triggered ability put on the stack. Giving Higure first strike will mean that the triggered ability that searches for a Ninja will be put on the stack and can be responded to. If the creature doesn't have any triggered abilities, it can't be cast between first strike and regular damage steps.
74587: Ninja of the Deep Hours.text_posted:
@Ladon

You can only activate Ninjutsu after First strike damage is dealt if there's a triggered ability put on the stack. Giving [autocard multiverseid="74448"]Higure[/autocard] first strike will mean that the triggered ability that searches for a Ninja will be put on the stack and can be responded to. If the creature doesn't have any triggered abilities, it can't be cast between first strike and regular damage steps.

74594: Ogre Marauder.author: OlvynChuru
74594: Ogre Marauder.text_parsed:
Ogre Marauder is an absolutely amazing card. Sometimes its ability is actually better than simply being unblockable all the time because it allows you to trick your opponents. For example, let's say it's your turn and you have out Ogre Marauder, while your opponent has a Llanowar Elves and a Leatherback Baloth. You attack, they sacrifice their elf to make the ogre blockable... and then you play Geth's Verdict, making them sacrifice their baloth and lose 1 life, and they ALSO take 3 from the ogre.

4/5

74597: Takeno's Cavalry.author: Reversed
74597: Takeno's Cavalry.text_parsed:
This card is kind of depressing. Any of you read the Kamigawa novels? This card's flavor is pretty awesome. Why does it have to be so damn terrible? In fact, that's the one part that's off. Takeno had extremely well trained men. A 1/1? Get out of here with that.

As a 3/3 he'd be playable, with an ability that is pretty marginal these days. The same would be true if he cost 1W, and stayed as a 1/1. Considering the importance of spirits in his block's makeup, I'd even accept 2W as a cost, or 2/2 as his P/T.

But right now, he's jut no good. I rated it a 1.5/5 because he does at least have some good synergy with other cards due to his Samurai type.

74600: Minamo Sightbender.author: Equinox523
74600: Minamo Sightbender.text_parsed:
An interesting blue variation of the old Dwarven Warriors strategy of attacking, then pumping after they are unblockable. This came in the Betrayers of Kamigawa Ninja pre-con, where it was a decent Ninjitsu enabler. It works best with initially low-power creatures, so you don't have to pay a ton for its ability, saving more for pumping it. Char-Rumbler comes to mind as a nice target for this.

If you hang around long enough, Vraska the Unseen's tokens can win you games with help from this. Just saying.

74607: Orb of Dreams.author: MechaKraken
74607: Orb of Dreams.text_parsed:
This thing shuts down aggro decks almost single-handedly, something many decks can take advantage of. I know there are a few other alternatives, such as Kismet or Blind Obedience, but this is an ARTIFACT. It enables decks like mono-red burn or blue/black control to have a one card defense against haste and other aggro keywords. It also taps everything, unlike the other two cards.

As Mode mentioned, Amulet of Vigor can make this even better to use. I'd also suggest running a lot of non-basic lands that enter tapped, such as the gates or manlands, simply because they don't have a drawback anymore with their 'come into play tapped' ability rendered inert.

74607: Orb of Dreams.author: kiseki
74607: Orb of Dreams.text_parsed:
Use Orb of Dreams with Amulet of Vigor and the new inspired creatures to cause them to trigger immediately, and anytime you flicker them.

Blue and Black have any good choices which do not require additional mana:
Arbiter of the Ideal
Daring Thief
Disciple of Deceit
King Macar, the Gold-Cursed
Servant of Tymaret
Siren of the Silent Song
Sphinx's Disciple

Then use Conjurer's Closet to get some bonus uses out of them.
Use Mimic Vat to trigger them on demand.

74612: Vital Surge.author: allmighty_abacus
74612: Vital Surge.text_parsed:
Nourish.

You'd have to splice this card twice to get the same effect. Or once, and then hardcast it. Or hardcast two. Whatever, you get the idea. Although, if you're depending on pure lifegain cards to save you in green (when you should be overrunning your opponent with an army of tokens or elves or beasts), I got news for you...

If you really want to gain some life, at least do something like respite in response to your opponent's alpha strike, or net yourself some card advantage with momentous fall once a creature has outlived its usefulness.

This card is rated low because it's just not very good. It does nothing but net you a measly 3 life. Some would say "oh but it splices and is arcane so you can splice onto it!" To that I I just yawn in your face. It sounds like it would be a fun mechanic, but like the whole rest of the block it was just too underpowered. I really wouldn't be ever be impressed by tacking 3 life onto any spell for 2 extra mana. And yet again, there are no other splice or arcane cards outside kamigawa.

You people need to realize that not every card needs to be rated 4 to 5 stars because it won you a casual game or two way back in the day when nobody in your playgroup was working yet and couldn't afford to buy more than a couple of booster packs. You have to take into account all other formats (and even todays' kitchen table casual gaming) and in the grand scheme of magic, this just doesn't pull its own weight.

This does have a place in arcane-based green decks that are looking for a way to slow the game. Yes there are lots of spells with more efficient life gain, but you can't look at Splice spells strictly from a cost-effect point of view. That said, if you are playing a deck that this will fit well in, I have to ask: why are you playing an green Arcane combo deck!?!

74612: Vital Surge.author: Enelysios
74612: Vital Surge.text_parsed:
This card is pretty awful. Healing Leaves is the same, plus the ability to protect a creature, for half the cost. Does the splice make up for that? Meh, not really. They should have given this Splice . Still I use it in my green spiritcraft EDH because there are only 13 arcane spells in green, and only 4 have splice. Of all of them this is probably 3rd from the worst, but hey, at least its not Nourishing Shoal? Honestly I plan on taking it out of that deck evevntually, but I get so few chances to use splice that I have been stubbornly keeping it in. I have spliced both it and Kodama's Might onto a spell a few times, and that does play out pretty neatly.

Splice is another example of a cool mechanic that Kamigawa ruined by being under-powered and parasitic. (Having no support or interactions outside of the block.) Splice is incredibly unique and a lot of fun to play with for the same reason that people love enchanting and equipping creatures; it is fun to create custom spells! However, very few people will ever see it in action because there are probably about a half dozen great arcane spells (Kodama's Reach is the good one that Green got) and the rest are absolutely terrible. The only chance you will have to have fun with splice is in Kamigawa block constructed, and that's just because you enemies will be playing with awful cards too.

They revisited ninjas in Planechase, I hope they do the same with splice and give us some cards at a playable power level, since I doubt we will ever see an official return to the much maligned Kamigawa.

74615: Splinter.author: Azazyel
74615: Splinter.text_parsed:
@The Dark One: You wouldn't be able to fetch this with Clarion Ultimatum by targeting a Splinter token from Splintering Winds. A "Splinter token" is a nameless creature that has "Creature - Splinter" as its card type and subtype, respectively. Tokens don't have names unless specified.

As an example, see Tolsimir Wolfblood. His ability puts a "Wolf token" named Voja onto the battlefield. Without the named clause, tokens put into play by a card or ability are essentially nameless.
74615: Splinter.text_posted:
@The Dark One: You wouldn't be able to fetch this with Clarion Ultimatum by targeting a Splinter token from Splintering Winds. A "Splinter token" is a nameless creature that has "Creature - Splinter" as its card type and subtype, respectively. Tokens don't have names unless specified.

As an example, see [autocard]Tolsimir Wolfblood[/autocard]. His [T] ability puts a "Wolf token" [i]named[/i] Voja onto the battlefield. Without the [i]named[/i] clause, tokens put into play by a card or ability are essentially nameless.

74620: Patron of the Kitsune.author: kiseki
74620: Patron of the Kitsune.text_parsed:
This is not an easy card to use, as the tension is very bad. Do you sacrifice a fox right before their attack or afterwards? On one hand, you want to gain the life, and on the other you want to chomp one of the attackers, and you can't have it both ways unless your opponent is already desperate. Worst case, you throw it down before the attack, they kill it with a spell getting a two-for-one off of you, and now you are wide open.
All that said, it is a solid body for a good price (for white at least) that impacts the board the turn you play it. There are a lot of powerful, non-legendary angels competing for the 6 mana slot in your decks though...
The best use I can think of is to attack with your Samurai of the Pale Curtains and you sac whichever one gets munched by their big blocker. You can still get two-for-oned, but maybe you did some damage to your opponent in the meantime to make up for it. And if not then then might have held back blockers thinking to swing with you wide open the next turn.

74620: Patron of the Kitsune.author: TheWrathofShane
74620: Patron of the Kitsune.text_parsed:
You actually cant gain take advantage of the ability without your opponent knowing about it beforehand. This has to be on the field before they declare attackers or the ability does not trigger. And if this guys out, they can just choose not to attack. This might actually be a design flaw, since his fox offering wants you to cast him on their turn.

Then again, this might be what the designers intended. Cast him the phase before declare attackers, and now you just gave there aggro deck a tough decision. If they dont swing, then its mission accomplished for the turn. If they do, take something out and null the attack. But it might be more beneficial to flash him in as a blocker, depending if something must be taken out or not.

Thats enough theory crafting for today, and I am sure the designers knew what they were doing with this guy. Anyways, for its time it had a fantastic cost + body, a decent ability, and a way to cheat it out for far less, giving it flash. All things considered, including the terrific art + flavor, I am going to rate this a generous 4.5/5

74626: Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni.author: Ferlord
74626: Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni.text_parsed:
I think Okiba-Gang Shinobi works well with this card. Almost in every way was both cards made for each other.

Black + Rat Ninja + Ninjutsu + Effects sort of gives both chemistry. I, however, do not like the fact that you can't bring creatures from your graveyard out. That is why the Okiba's effect is pretty efficient and can help Ink-Eyes effect.

THe one thing i find confusing is when she's called Ink-Eyes, and all i see in her eyes is a trail of red... fiery mist of whatever. I understand that she is a servant of oni's, but then call her "Blood-Eyes" or something if so.

Or maybe the people of Kamigawa are strange and like writing in red. Blood red... Interesting :P

74626: Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni.author: Arachnos
74626: Ink-Eyes, Servant of Oni.text_parsed:
I find it interesting that she's the "servant of Oni" and yet she's more powerful and useful than the majority of actual Onis. Although, according to her story, "A Servant's Mission", the "oni" in question is actually Kuro, Pitlord, who is pretty damn badass of his own right.

Also, I like how she can slaughter her human blue counterpart, Higure, the Still Wind in combat, without even using her regeneration. She's fairly more powerful than him too, since contrarily to him she doesn't need the synergy of a Ninja deck to be playable. Nevertheless, they combo together in a blue-black deck as well - Higure can help bring her out, as well as make her unblockable for her reanimation effect to really kick in.

@Ferlord: You're not the only one to be bothered by this, and while the theory is interesting, I found out that the blood trails are a result of the recent power boost Kuro gave her. Presumably, her name dates from back when she still had black eyes, like any rat.

74627: Traproot Kami.author: Champion_Kitsune
74627: Traproot Kami.text_parsed:
Sort of bad early game (compare to Wall of Roots, Wall of Blossoms, or Vine Trellis), but in the late game, an unstoppable wall.

Also, it has the potential to be better than the walls I just mentioned if your opponent is playing green too.

That said, this card is really only good in mono-green, where you can maximize your forests, and in casual, when you don't have nearly as many nonbasics.

74629: Roar of Jukai.author: Gemstone386
74629: Roar of Jukai.text_parsed: OpenSeasonNoobs is incorrect. A card's splice ability can only be once per arcane spell cast. So you can only use Roar of Jukai up to four times when you cast Reach Through Mists, and even then you would need 4 of these in your hand.
74629: Roar of Jukai.text_posted: OpenSeasonNoobs is incorrect. A card's splice ability can only be once per arcane spell cast. So you can only use Roar of Jukai up to four times when you cast Reach Through Mists, and even then you would need 4 of these in your hand.

74629: Roar of Jukai.author: OmegaSerris
74629: Roar of Jukai.text_parsed:
Such a horribly specific card. This SO needed to grant trample. At best, you can hope to combo in an Overrun effect so the added trample gives this some purpose (if you went the splice route), otherwise you MIGHT kill off a wall or you'll probably just overkill a chump blocker or two by even more. And why the Forest condition? What purpose does that serve? Would it REALLY be that overpowered splashed in another color deck? REALLY?

I hate to call any card trash, but when it's only really functions on a full moon during a July snowstorm, you can't say much else about it.

74629: Roar of Jukai.author: Enelysios
74629: Roar of Jukai.text_parsed:
Works well when combo'd with Kodama of the South Tree. All your creatures other than the Kodama get trample and +1/+1 from spiritcraft. You then finish off the overrun effect with this. Better when you use the splice of course.

What this card suffers from is a lack of good Green arcane to splice onto. Green/red or green/blue will get better use here.

74629: Roar of Jukai.author: GrimjawxRULES
74629: Roar of Jukai.text_parsed: I quite like this card. With 3 creatures blocked you're giving a total of +6/+6 for free by giving your opponent 5 life. I'd gladly give my opponent 5 life if it means killing 3 blocking creatures and completely crushing his board state. Also works great with Kavu Predator as I think others have mentioned, but keep in mind that you won't have the Predator each and every game, so you've got to consider if this card is still useful for your deck at times when you're not attacking with one of those.

74637: Floodbringer.author: Cyberium
74637: Floodbringer.text_parsed:
Functionally, Floodbringer and Rishadan Port aren't too different, both uses two lands to tap one. Floodbringer is a creature that has flying and can attack, which also makes it vulnerable to destroy effect and counter spells. However, it can tap multiple lands all by itself and enables landfall for cheap.

All moonfolk decks should have Exploration and or Manabond in mind. Suddenly, Floodbringer's ability becomes scary.

74642: Lifespinner.author: Mode
74642: Lifespinner.text_parsed:
I guess this fellow was inspired by Dark Supplicant.
Unfortunately though, it was not such an awesome one-drop, so you won't be able to use his ability in turn two with two other one-drops. And another downside is that it can only search in the library.
Then on the other hand, you can search for any legendary spirit.
Overall this guy should do a good job, especially since "Spirit" is a handy type. There are Spirit cards which can be returned from the graveyard with Soulshift or inherent abilities, or you can use spells which create Spirit tokens which are useful for saccing without great card disadvantage.

so, far, counting all the spoilers, plus assuming That Which Was Taken makes it, I'm count three cards I'm excited for, three that I don't know why they're even in the set. Kikki Jikki at least has fans, even if I'm not one of them. Sun Quan was not the P3K card we were looking for, but he's alright too. Doran is the third off-beat legend that I might have liked in the set if he weren't one of the 'best' in what looks like its gonna the biggest 'failed the hype' in Magic ever.

That makes a total of:
3 cards that really are Mythic Legends (Teferi, TWWT, Progenitus)
3 cards that will be cool to get in foil (Doran, Kikki Jikki, Sun Quan)
3 cards that will therefore have the alternate arts wasted on them (Rafiq, Kresh, Rafiq)
and 6 unknown cards, probably from Homelands if Wizards keep up the pattern.
If Malfegor is in, you will actually be better off getting Alara block Booster Boxes than FTV: Legends. which is just...ugh...unfortunately, Malfegor is a Demon Dragon, and actually kind of likely.

74644: That Which Was Taken.author: Dunquixote
74644: That Which Was Taken.text_parsed:
In response to RKD2222's comment asking if this could be used on a planeswalker: since the card text says 'permanent' and doesn't specify what type of permanent you can put the counter on, until the card's rulings are updated, if you decide to use a divinity counter on it, then it would be indestructible. In Mark Rosewater's article, "Planeswalker Rules," he wrote that: "Any spell or ability that affects a permanent (for example, "destroy target permanent") can affect a planeswalker. Note that planeswalkers aren't creatures; if a card says it affects a creature, it won't affect a planeswalker."

In addition to that, regarding permanents in general with the counter on them, I think it is fair to say That Which Was Taken really isn't OP because there are still plenty of ways to "get rid of" the permanent that has a divinity counter on it--for example exile or remove x amount of counters off of all permanents. Any spell that targets permanents except for cards that says "destroy target permanent" would affect it. If I am mistaken, please do correct me.

Personally, I love this card, in spite of how easily a person can find a way to "get rid of" a permanent, or destroy/remove the artifact itself. When I'm facing a deck that lacks the cards to destroy artifacts, subtract toughness from a creature (if the counter is on a creature) remove permanents from the game, etc, I have a better chance of winning; if I get the artifact out fast enough and put a counter on a permanent that is crucial to not lose, then it still can hinder the opponent for a decent amount of turns before they destroy it.

74644: That Which Was Taken.author: Mode
74644: That Which Was Taken.text_parsed:
Awesome name. Awesome artwork. Terrible card.

How did this get a 4 Star rating? That's way too much.
If cards were to be rated by name, I would rate this 6/5.

But 4/5 for design? Definitely not:
You'll have to pay the first time to make a permanent indestructible while this is in play.
And your opponent can still exile it, bounce it, flicker it, etc.

For that amount of mana, you could have cast two bigger threats instead of inreliably trying to protect something else.

(I remember thinking highly of this card when I started playing, so maybe it has something to do with the fact that new casual players tend to get mislead by the concept behind it.)

It should in the very least not be possible for your opponent to shatter TWWT.
We have Darksteel Plate for creatures these days, which offers just that and costs you half as much mana.

74644: That Which Was Taken.author: Reishyn
74644: That Which Was Taken.text_parsed:
Konda's reason for stealing That Which Was Taken was because he felt that after spending his entire lifetime building a prosperous empire that it was unfair to lose it to old age. So he performed a ritual to steal this from the spirit world. It's implied in the books that it's literally the spirit of the impossible; a Kami that represents everything beyond the bounds of reality. Which would also make it the Kami of Kami in a roundabout sort of way. That's why, alongside the whole stealing a god thing, Konda possessing it was such an abomination. Konda possessing it was him declaring dominion over the Kami themselves and upsetting the natural order. It's also why (SPOILERS) it was able to defeat O-Kagachi, the Kami of All Things when released thus saving the realm. (END SPOILERS) With it, Konda hoped to master both the real and immaterial, life and death, spirit and mundane and create an everlasting empire that would never die.

Or at least that might have been his original intention. It becomes pretty clear that his obsession with is rather unhealthy when he spends twenty odd years locked away in a tower with it just to make sure he can always be near the thing. He seems to treasure it much more than his daughter Michiko too. Also, when Toshiro Umezawa confronts him in his throne room and makes off with it he quickly degrades from a badass, immortal samurai emperor to a terrified old man desperate to get back the only thing keeping death at bay for him as soon as possible.

This isn't nearly as bad as it seems (which is pretty darn bad).
If your opponent has no need to cast the spells in their hand, this guy isn't going to be nearly as much of an incentive as, say, Hypnotic Specter or its ilk.
Plus late game, they're in top deck mode, and unless they're topping loads of instants or flash spells, they'll be eating or chumping 5 a turn.

If nothing else he could be decent in casual, or pauper variants that allow uncommons.

74646: Patron of the Nezumi.author: majinara
74646: Patron of the Nezumi.text_parsed:
I like him as a Commander for the Commander format. :)

- 6/6 is a decent size for a commander, allowing him to realistically kill people with Commander damage, while surviving some burn and combat
- with the rat offering, there are ways to keep his casting cost managable, especially regarding the cost increase due to him dying every now and then
- with rat offering he can be played at instant speed, which is always great (as a surprise blocker, to keep mana open for instants, to make sure he can attack before sorcery speed removal hits him), but is even greater on him, since you can play him in response to mass removal. He might die, but might cause a lot of life loss too
- the ability is great for multiplayer games
- flavorful and good art
- there is quite a number of great rats out there, for a rat deck
- you don't have to tap him for his abilities, so you can get an advantage out of it, while still attacking and blocking

74647: Hokori, Dust Drinker.author: Mode
74647: Hokori, Dust Drinker.text_parsed:
Winter Orb on legendary legs. An interesting tool for a control deck.

Although you likely won't want to use both simultaneously since this would allow untapping two lands.
Anyways, Stoneshaker Shaman does a great job with this guy if you're splashing red.
Spelltithe Enforcer, Loxodon Gatekeeper, Kismet and Orb of Dreams also work nicely with this guy (or the Winter Orb).
If you add any other forms of mana accel to your deck you'll get a big advantage from doing so.
Mana Cache can have use for this deck in particular (and Mana Geyser would have too if it wasn't simply that awful), Braid of Fire also works nicely, and any mana artifacts like Chrome Mox or Mox Diamond easily allow to cast Hokori earlier, too.

74647: Hokori, Dust Drinker.author: Rendin
74647: Hokori, Dust Drinker.text_parsed: Note the "on their controllers' untap steps" clause. If you can find a way to make your lands untap on THEIR phase, they're all set to go when your turn comes around. A good example of how to do this is an artifact land-heavy deck (or Mycosynth Lattice if you can manage the 6 colorless) and an Unwinding Clock. I use the lattice/clock combo in an artifact deck to keep up a solid defense during opponents' turns, but it's just as applicable here in crippling opponents' mana supplies but leaving yours mostly unaffected.

74652: Threads of Disloyalty.author: jonrds
74652: Threads of Disloyalty.text_parsed:
@raptorman333
Control magic is not legal in the Modern format (it has been reprinted for Commander, but other than that, it isn't legal in much). Additionally, many modern decks are built to win on turn 2-3, which increases the need for a low cost enchantment and actually mitigates the drawback (since a lot of the creatures you see will be below 2 cmc). Put those two together and you get why this card is $13+.

Its not just the fact that the defender was given rules text rather than the bushido, but they divided the two with a semi-colon...it just looks silly.

Did this card really need to have Bushido 1? It can't attack with it, and although the +1 power matters the +1 toughness doesn't as much, since this yojimbo can prevent damage dealt to him. Rants aside, love this guy. A walking sword-wielding fox with a straw bowl on his head! :D

74655: Opal-Eye, Konda's Yojimbo.author: nemokara
74655: Opal-Eye, Konda's Yojimbo.text_parsed:
@Splizer and Shiny_Umbreon

It may seem weird for defender to have reminder text while bushido doesn't, but this was actually the first set where defender became a keyword. So this was one of the first three creatures with defender, along with Kaijin of the Vanishing Touch and Traproot Kami. Before this, only Walls had the 'can't attack' ability, so it's understandable that players would need some reminding of the change. In contrast, they had had an entire set already to play with the bushido mechanic, making it okay to omit the reminder text on a wordy rare.
74655: Opal-Eye, Konda's Yojimbo.text_posted:

74666: Genju of the Spires.author: SAUS3
74666: Genju of the Spires.text_parsed:
Fantastic card. It turns basic lands into manlands! Also, you can be pretty mean against people who use mountains, or lots of non-basic lands (combined with bloodmoon).

For more linear use, put it on a mountain on turn 1. Then, later, when you have about 4 or 5 mana, use burns to clear the way, and swing in for 6 damage each turn. If they kill your land, you can just move to a new one.

I want to use this because it is really good at getting around blue control decks. On turn 1, they won't be able to counter it (most likely), and they can't stop it from becoming a creature. It's quite a dangerous card.

74668: Gods' Eye, Gate to the Reikai.author: Yukikah
74668: Gods' Eye, Gate to the Reikai.text_parsed:
Pretty much an auto-include in a colorless deck though, especially a Karn or Kozilek EDH deck. When you only need colorless mana, sticking one of these in your deck is just insurance against land destruction, if nothing else.

Wouldn't put it ahead of other colorless lands such as Darksteel Citadel, Rishadan Port, Strip Mine, or etc. But definitely room to stick one in for no loss in efficiency.

74669: Patron of the Moon.author: Kamishini
74669: Patron of the Moon.text_parsed:
Okay! So I thought of an infinite mana any color combo with this card, Oboro Breezecaller, Lotus Vale, and two other lands on the field that don't bounce other land.

Step 1: Tap Lotsu Vale for three {W} {U} {B} {R} {G}.
Step 2: Pay {2} to bounce misc. land with Oboro Breezecaller's ability. Untap Lotus Vale. One floating mana of the color tapped with Lotus Vale.
Step 3: Repeat Step 1 than 2. Two mana floating of any color.
Step 4: Pay {1} to place the two land you bounced into play with Patron of the Moon's ability. One mana of any color you choose left floating.
Step 5: Repeat Steps 1 through 4 for infinite mana of any color combination!

Yay! I think I semi-redeemed Oboro Breezecaller, with it's absolutely GORGEOUS artwork!

Sorry for any formatting issues, and I'm sure someone else has though of this before, but I didn't see it posted up here so... And I know it's fragile, but hey! Who's gonna suspect Oboro Breezecaller as part of an infinite mana combo?

74671: Cunning Bandit // Azamuki, Treach.author: OpeeFomenom
74671: Cunning Bandit // Azamuki, Treach.text_parsed:
Actually, there are a number of things you can do with this. It can essentially stop you opponent from attacking altogether. When they attack, gain control of any creatures they don't use and have them block for you. With enough counters you can at least lock them down for a few turns. Otherwise you can gain control of their blockers and attack unblocked.

This can also combo with Crack the Earth to sacrifice two of their creatures. I use this AND the Kirin in my deck. It's fun to work with. I love that you don't HAVE to flip these cards when the requirement is met. I can charge as many Ki counters as I feel I need.

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: CalebTheTimeTraveler
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
This card works great in a Sunburst Deck. With some Chromatic Spheres and some Guild Lands, this can be dropped by turn 4.
As for the debate of weather this card works, if you pay its coast in succession, it stays a Creature, essentially having to pay 4 to use it. Of course, because of that, unless you have alot of disposable Mana, it can really hurt you during multi-player games, but if your playing a Sunburst deck, you shouldn't worry about damage that much, unless it's coming your way, which makes this sort of like an Instant defender.

Of course, because of that, unless you have alot of disposable Mana, it can really hurt you during multi-player games, but if your playing a Sunburst deck, you shouldn't worry about damage that much, unless it's coming your way, which makes this sort of like an Instant defender.

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: KicktheCAN
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
Summoning sickness checks whether the permanent has been controlled continuously since the beginning of your turn. A non-creature permanent that becomes a creature is subject to summoning sickness if you have not controlled that permanent since the beginning of your turn.

As long as you did not play the land that turn, it does not have summoning sickness.

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: allmighty_abacus
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
No! Bad community! Baaad!

Guys, first of all this is a legend from the kamigawa block. A legendary enchantment at that. How can an enchantment be legendary? If it were a man land that would make sense, but as is, it's just stupid.

Secondly for everyone saying zOMFG 8/12 TRAMPLE EPIC WIN SUPER POWER 5 STARS it's not even a creature most of the time. You have to pay mana for it. To activate a legendary enchantment. An enchantment, which are notoriously bad for card advantage. I mean, what if someone eye of nowhered the land on their turn after you dropped this? Good job, you're down a land and lost your precious legendary enchantment. I mean, manlands offer a similiar effect without *** over both card advantage and mana curve. Jesus christ people come on. 4.5 stars is dumb.

And just because it's rather large and has trample when it does decide to be a creature, it is still a legend. Pretty unworthy of legendary status if you ask me. It's like one of the legends from Legends, except instead of having an unspeakably absurd casting cost it screws card advantage and doesn't do anything unless you pay additional mana. Every turn.

Half a star to lower the stupidly high rating.

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: NARFNra
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
@allmighty_abacus

Why hallo there, I'm here to counter your points.

First of all, "Guys, first of all this is a legend from the kamigawa block. A legendary enchantment at that. How can an enchantment be legendary? If it were a man land that would make sense, but as is, it's just stupid."

Flavor argument, not worth discussing.

"Secondly for everyone saying zOMFG 8/12 TRAMPLE EPIC WIN SUPER POWER 5 STARS it's not even a creature most of the time. You have to pay mana for it. To activate a legendary enchantment. An enchantment, which are notoriously bad for card advantage. I mean, what if someone eye of nowhered the land on their turn after you dropped this? Good job, you're down a land and lost your precious legendary enchantment. I mean, manlands offer a similiar effect without *** over both card advantage and mana curve. Jesus christ people come on. 4.5 stars is dumb."

Okay, let's say it was a 8/12 creature. Turn after you play it, during it's summoning sickness, they can Eye To Nowhere it can't they? So you're saying all creatures that don't have an enters the battlefield effect or haste are useless?

As for the mana cost, it's 1 one of each color plus 2 to get an 8/12 trampler. And every turn after that, you can pay 2 to call up 12 points of toughness.

As for manlands, manlands are subject to this thing called "1 land per turn". And since most of them are targetable as much as this is, and CAN'T be replayed because they don't go to the graveyard, I'd say they're worse.

"And just because it's rather large and has trample when it does decide to be a creature, it is still a legend. Pretty unworthy of legendary status if you ask me. It's like one of the legends from Legends, except instead of having an unspeakably absurd casting cost it screws card advantage and doesn't do anything unless you pay additional mana. Every turn."

I'm not sure whether this is supposed to be a mechanical argument or flavor ranting. Sure, it's legendary. I think Wizards is smart enough to not let players have a turn where they activate 4 different 8/12's with trample for 8 mana, or 2 for 4 mana. Mirror Gallery DOES allow it though...

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
I think it's peculiar that the spirit creature is legendary too. I mean, unless you run Mirror Gallery...

Ah, I get it, I think. There are cards, at least one in the Kamigawa block, I think, that can move enchantments. But Kitsune Mystic (as Autumn-Tail, Kitsune Sage) would not work, the other target must be a creature too.

Heh. But if you get this to work... You can actually put it on your opponents lands, switch, and blast two, then get Genju of the Realm back. Yeah, way too complicated and costly, but hey, reusable land destruction.

Still, I wonder why the land gets no new name.

Also, just for crazy casual, this + Darksteel Citadel + Jokulhaups (or Devastation or Obliterate, but those cost more).

Finally, the flavor is awesome. And that it's the only multicolored card in the entire set.

75364: Genju of the Realm.author: Gandlodder
75364: Genju of the Realm.text_parsed:
This card is interesting to me for a couple of reasons, and not just because he's a drooling, world-sized Akki. I'm a little surprised no one has yet mentioned these trivia points.

This is the only Legendary Aura printed thus far.

This was the first multicolored card printed in the post-8th Edition card frame.

I remember speculating with my high school buddies whether or not gold cards would be printed in the new style or not, or if they would switch to something more along the lines of what eventually showed up on split-color cards. Lo and behold, we ended up with both!

4.5/5 for flavor, usefulness, and oddball facts

81976: Jetting Glasskite.text_parsed: An exceptionally tactile creature that forces your opponent to waste extra removal spells is amazing. 81976: Jetting Glasskite.author: leomistico
81976: Jetting Glasskite.text_parsed:
Have a nice body, big enought to attire the attention of the opponent and have it wish to target it. A bit costy, but can live a lot longer than Air Elemental. Just play cards that target opponent's creature, not yours, and this can be a real beater! Also, virtual card advantage, since if your opponent doesn't want to waste a removal to "break" the shield, he/she have a dead card in hand... Even better if he/she doesn't have 2 removal in hand...
For me, a little understimated
4/5

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: stygimoloch
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
Something's wrong when creatureless decks run four copies of a Legendary equipment maindeck, just to nullify the opponent's... however I'm still glad it was printed because as with Mindslaver, it can be quite a fun card to lose against, since games involving it almost always turn out weird and convoluted and interesting. It also does a good job of making you feel, when it comes down, that you must have an out somewhere if only you can think of it. True enough at the end of the day it's just an artifact and one Shatter will kill it... ah, the rock/paper/scissors beauty of magic. I still agree with Claov though, it could have been playtested more and tuned better.

You know the worst thing though? In the book Toshi has TWO of these. Gah.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: IHERO
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed: I do understand that many people have had heart-ache about this card.  Yes, I do believe the card is dominate however I feel as I have always felt when people start talking about banning this card or another, that in the end by banning cards you are taking away from the game.  The real problem is not with this card or any other for that matter, it is with people being stuck on the best deck concept.  It is very common now to walk into even a small level event a find a field made up of players playing either one of two decks.  So what I am getting at is answers for any strategy or card always exist, people as a whole are just to lazy to come up with an original strategy of their own.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: trevathecleva
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed: I can't believe they banned the top and let this overpowered crap get bye! I love to hate this card, because its the essence of bad (overpowered) card design and lack of proper testing prior to release of a set. It's also rare and $-expensive-$, so aggro players who don't have have one lose to it in the mirror. Another reason Jitte is broken is that it's played even in control decks with a ridiculously small amount of creatures, and still exploited. It allows too many powerful choices and is sooooo easy to trigger. It irks me that they feel proud enough of this card to have made a promo version!

I love to hate this card, because its the essence of bad (overpowered) card design and lack of proper testing prior to release of a set. It's also rare and $-expensive-$, so aggro players who don't have have one lose to it in the mirror. Another reason Jitte is broken is that it's played even in control decks with a ridiculously small amount of creatures, and still exploited. It allows too many powerful choices and is sooooo easy to trigger. It irks me that they feel proud enough of this card to have made a promo version!

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: Asmodi0000
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
This is a cruel card. There are some cards that make people groan and moan whenever it hits the battlefield, and there's even a few who deserve such a reputation.

If you go to a casual game with a jitte, you probably should expect to lose a few friends. It's not an instant win card, but it's so close to being one, and so powerful compared to the majority of the cards in the game, that with this card you basically rob and steal games, rather than win them.

It's fine to own and to use in tournaments, but keep it away from the kitchen table.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: GrimjawxRULES

I don't get people who are upset with this card. Really, I've never had a boring game when an opponent cast this. Granted, it DOES put a lot of pressure on you, but at the same time it doesn't steal the game right away, and you still get time to respond to it before you lose. I'd much rather have my opponent casting this on his/her second turn than a Hymn to Tourach. Really, there are more boring cards out there.

5/5, because this card provides for some interesting games without being a decisive win.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: Okuu-chan
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
The Jitte is one of the most efficient, powerful, and card-advantageous artifacts ever printed. I'm playing with a lot of younger players (students at the school I teach at), and when I drop the Jitte I tell them "This piece of equipment will kill all your creatures." They scoff at it, because it doesn't have "Destroy" on it.

Then I contribute to their education.

"Predator Ooze! Ha! It's indestructible!"
"-1/-1. It dies."

"...okay then. Ambush viper! Ha! It will kill your Ghost Council!"
"-1/-1. It dies."
...
"Darnit, no blockers."
"Okay, take 9 damage from Angel of Despair."
"Huh?! Why?!"
"+4/+4 from the Jitte."

...
"You're dead!"
"No, I gain two life from the Jitte."

BTW, the pronunciation is "zhi-TEH." It's not "jeet" or "jittay." It's amazing how a parrying weapon, of all things, is more efficient at destruction than an apocalypse sword Worldslayer.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: Chrs84
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
Jitte go home; get out of here. Legendary artifact, you sure got that right.
Personally I refuse to play with it, although it's kind of a moral issue with me and a belief that I don't need it, I mostly don't use it because a friend of mind has fallen in love with it, so it's unofficially become his forte.
The downside to what it promotes in the theory and technical deck/gameplay building skill is that sometimes my friend has a deck idea that he can't seem to bring to full or supposed full potential, then he adds the Jitte and lots of his problems are solved.
The question remains though: in those instances, was it just the right card his decks needed or was his decks generally or overall mediocre/flawed?
I don't want to knock one card as playing a critical role in a deck's success, there's nothing really wrong with that although practicality may suggest not putting all eggs in one basket (relying predominantly or exclusively on any one particular card).
It's a tough call. So for me, I like to think I can tell when a deck/gameplay is solid and effective fundamentally with good synergy as opposed to having a disorganized flow but some super-duper card that makes-up for things.

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: Haelthor
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
I've recently acquired one of these beauties and found a temporary home for it in my EDH/Commander deck until I get the cards to use it in Legacy. However, ever since I've played a tournament with it in Damia, Sage of Stone I don't think I ever want to take it out.

Here are some used commanders that can be taken down with one swing from Jitte:
Gaddock Teeg
Edric, Spymaster of Trest
Kaalia of the Vast
Jhoira of the Ghitu
Azami, Lady of Scrolls
Captain Sisay
Momir Vig, Simic Visionary
Riku, of Two Reflections
Sygg, River Guide
Adun Oakenshield
Arcum Daggson
Anima, Soul of Elements (if you catch him small enough, or after a board wipe)
Kira, Great Glass Spinner (granted you need at least 3 counters to kill her, but you're not losing any cards to do so).
And those are just the tip of the iceberg of 2 toughness commanders that people use, not to mention utility creatures that can be off'd very easily.

Jitte is an absolutely brilliant utility card: disruption, pump and emergency life gain all wrapped up together. In my deck I don't need the combat phase to win, preferring to hold back on blockers so I can to buy time to combo off, but the inclusion of this one card lets me utilize an entire part of my turn that would otherwise be wasted. Jitte certainly steers the game in its owner's favor, and asks each opponent to kill it quickly before the disruption it provides grinds out additional card advantage, but it can also be dealt with via relic breakers and even Phyrexian Metamorph (legendary).

81979: Umezawa's Jitte.author: ShatterPalm
81979: Umezawa's Jitte.text_parsed:
For those of you who are curious how the flavor works, Toshiro Umezawa is a Kanji mage and Hyozan reckoner, capable of crafting Kanji symbols that, when given fuel and activated, provide a variety of effects. The fuel is more often than not blood.
As for his Jittes, they work by giving him a medium through which he can craft more potent magic. The tips of the Jittes are spiked so they can more easily draw blood, hence the "when equipped creature deals combat damage" clause. After that he can draw any number of kanji that can mean any number of things. They can either increase his power, give him Final Fantasy style Buffs like Reflect, or harm and weaken his enemies more directly.
And yes, you read that right. Jittes. He has two. The one on the card here is his second Jitte, the more powerful of the two. It's made of an alloy of steel and silver and imbued with magic, turning it effectively into an amplifier. Any kanji he draws with this jitte is immensely more powerful than it would be otherwise.

Can you not HEAR those maddening, bone chilling, soul haunting screams of the flawless victory coming straight out of the cardboard cutting right through both your ears??! Cause.., It's DEAFANING!! 81983: Skullsnatcher.author: monstersexist
81983: Skullsnatcher.text_parsed:
4/5. This rat is actually fantastic. I've been tweeking my Rat Ninjutsu deck for a while and left this guy out because of his perk (my meta doesn't use alot of flashback so its no big to me about graveyard exiling). Compare in terms of damage to Throat Slitter. You're trading 2 mana for the perk of killing a nonblack assuming they have a nonblack. Still obv not as forceful as an Okiba-Gang or an Ink-Eyes but those are getting closer to bombs. This guy is great for those Turn 2-Turn 3 swings if you don't have something else ready, and rats can use any damage available to them, considering they're generally weak.
Turn1: Typhoid Rats
Turn2: They don't block because of Deathtouch, Ninjutsu out for and they take 2, you drop your typhoid rats back out for on turn 2 and have a Deathtouch blocker.

Also a good target to ninjutsu ravenous rats off.

81986: Overblaze.author: Maileesaeya
81986: Overblaze.text_parsed:
To... well, all previous commentors: Overblaze is one of the most dangerous cards in the game, with an almost endless list of possible cards to combo it with. The best part is that you can even just throw it on a regular creature to double its damage and pump it up just enough to finish a big opposing creature or one of your opponents. Chandra Nalaar is a particularly potent combo, as Donovan_Fabian noted, because by default, she does 10 damage to an opponent and everything he or she controls--enough to hurt that opponent and kill off most creatures in the game. However, having played games where creatures can easily get big enough to survive, doubling that damage is a very strong move, assuming your opponent survives, anyways (another common occurrence for me). And when comboed with Heartless Hidetsugu, anyone with odd life is down to 1, and anyone with even life is dead. Another advantage is that you can cast in on cards your opponents control--at one point, I was in a bad position, and my brother attacked his girlfriend with a 9/9. She was at 35 life, so she let it through. What neither of them expected was for me to smack Overblaze and Double Cleave on his 9/9, quadrupling the damage to 36 and killing her off, allowing me to take the game.

As I said, Overblaze is a remarkably potent card that works well in dozens of different combos. Since it only costs 4 mana, I'd say that's a pretty good deal. 5/5

81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.author: Lateralis0ne
81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.text_parsed:
I have a bizarre combo for this card....built into a Time Sieve deck.

Cards needed in play:
1 Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker
1 Time Sieve
at least 3 Ornithopter and/or Phyrexian Walker and/or Shield Sphere
1 (better if 2) Genesis Chamber

This combo can be hard to set up...except with tutors, plenty of denial for your opponent(s), and good old fashioned Card-Drawing-Power (Vedalken Archmage), it's fairly awesome. Still one of my favorite decks to play...with T. Academy, Paradise Mantle, Demonic Tutor...you can see where this is going.

81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.author: ProbablyThatGuy
81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.text_parsed:
@acemanner
I think you misread the card, as Shirei looks for power 1 or less, not toughness. You'd have to somehow lower Ball Lightning's power to 1 or less before he heads to the graveyard, which would probably be more trouble than its worth.

This guy is pretty limited in the cards that he can work with in regards to the entirety of MTG, but that said, he is an absolute blast to play if you can deal with the restrictions. Also remember to look for cards that end up with 1 or less power, not necessarily start that low, like Mindless Automaton or like heavyterror said, Pentavus and friends.

5/5 for a very unique legend with a fun design, and decently powerful if you build your deck around him.

Anyway, the long list of black (or colorless) creatures with power 1 or less that enjoy entering the battlefield or dying every turn:

Abyssal Gatekeeper
Ashen-Skin Zubera
Big Game Hunter
Black Cat
Blister Beetle

Fume Spitter
Infectious Host
Myr Moonvessel
Myr Retriever
Perilous Myr
Necropede
Ravenous Rats

And don't forget your free instant-speed sac outlets, so these abilities trigger each player's turn:

Spawning Pit
Altar of Dementia
Culling Dais
Viscera Seer

81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.author: igniteice
81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.text_parsed:
@BlackDoveProphet
When one enters the battlefield, it will be a 1/1. When the other enters the battlefield, it will be a 2/2 (having stolen the counters from the other). The other will die. At the end of the turn, you will return the Spike that died to the battlefield, and it will grab the counters from the other (now making it a 3/3), and the other will die. No lockdown.
81987: Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker.text_posted:

81989: Blinding Powder.author: Krysto
81989: Blinding Powder.text_parsed:
Puresteel Paladin essentially breaks this card outright when his ability kicks in.

You can, before combat, freely equip it to each creature, unattach it, then move it on to the next creature.

Us it with a Leonin Shikari and you can use it on your opponent's turns as well.

Essentially: "Prevent all combat damage that would be dealt to creatures you control". and it's only a 1-drop.
81989: Blinding Powder.text_posted:

81989: Blinding Powder.author: LordRandomness
81989: Blinding Powder.text_parsed:
Very neat with Palisade Giant, which is exceedingly hard to kill with noncombat damage and redirects every last point of combat damage onto itself. Honestly, this card's biggest issue is probably competition from Darksteel Plate (the plate is more expensive but has the same equip cost and only needs to be re-equipped when changing creatures, so assuming you use the powder once the plate has saved you mana overall). So what does this work better with?

Phyrexian Hydra, for starters. Witherscale Wurm for similar reasons. In general this is much better against infect/wither and is marginally better with instant speed equipping abilities like the Brass Squire exodus mentioned since you can protect multiple creatures a turn.

81991: Final Judgment.author: SleetFox
81991: Final Judgment.text_parsed:
This is one of the few cards that can get rid of creatures with the dynamic duo of indestructibility and shroud.

"Ha! I just cast Shield of the Oversoul and Clout of the Dominus on my Maelstrom Archangel! Taste 9/9 flying indestructible shroud haste free permanent action!"

...

*sobs*

OK, so there are probably more realistic situations where a creature will get both (my favorite is anything naturally indestructible + Diplomatic Immunity), but the point is a creature with both abilities is scary, and most people running the combination aren't going to expect anything to happen to their creature. This also destroys arcbound decks and a bunch of other things that don't mind when their creatures are destroyed. This card could be called situational, but there are a lot of situations where it's a MASSIVE unexpected disruption spell. At worst it's a slightly more potent Wrath of God for 2 more mana that works in control but not combo.

81991: Final Judgment.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
81991: Final Judgment.text_parsed:
Beyond awesome. You can also hide your best creatures in the Safe Haven!

Anyway, kind of sad they did not make O-Kagachi into a card as well.

Here's my take:

O-Kagachi, Kami of the All

Rare
Casting cost:
O-Kagachi, Kami of the All can't be countered.
If you play O-Kagachi, Kami of the All from your hand, it comes into play with a divinity counter.
When O-Kagachi, Kami of the All comes into play, exile all creatures.
O-Kagachi, Kami of the All is unblockable.
O-Kagachi, Kami of the All is indestructible.
At the end of any turn, remove a divinity counter from O-Kagachi, Kami of the All.
If there are no divinity counters on O-Kagachi, Kami of the All, you lose the game.
If O-Kagachi, Kami of the All were to be put into any graveyard from anywhere, shuffle it into your library instead.
12/12

So, same casting cost as Progenitus, a bit bigger, Final Judgment built in. I gave it unblockable and indestructible because it is the God of the Million Gods, come on! Unblockable also works against flash creatures or animatable statues. Library shuffle like Progenitus, but less powerful than the Eldrazi Titans.
I gave it the divinity counter clause to make it similar to Phage, The Untouchable - cheat it into play and you lose immediately. Also, it resembles Final Fortune in that it gives you one single chance to win (basically).
I did not give it protection from everything because then it would become almost totally unkillable. Now it can still be unsummoned, Pacified together with Vedalken Orrery, possibly prevented from attacking... At least some of these methods, like unsummoning it, imply that you will not lose if you do not win, and thanks to the creature board wipe, your opponent will also have to crawl back.

It combos naturally with That Which Was Taken, of course, and while the combo is powerful, it is prohibitivly expensive.

I also used Kamigawa-Block style wording - I hope. No entering the battlefield here.

Finally: Combos with Doubling Season!!! There, I said it.

81991: Final Judgment.author: TotalDomination
81991: Final Judgment.text_parsed: i have an issue with this card. the wording "Remove all creatures from the game" is too general. the word "all" means ALL and the word "game' means that one duel out of a match (since each duel is considered a game). creatures in your hand, library, graveyard, and play are included in the word "all" due to it being so general. so pretty much from my understanding, "remove all creatures from the game" should of been "remove all creatures in play from the game". therefore, the card has been misleading and has been used incorrectly unless Wizards reprints it or posts an official ruling, as it has none right now. So in conclusion, this card removes all creatures from play, all hands, all libraries, and all graveyards from the game. also, i own one of these, a wrath of god, Armageddon, obliterate, a door of nothingness and a coalition victory. and their all in certain decks.

So in conclusion, this card removes all creatures from play, all hands, all libraries, and all graveyards from the game. also, i own one of these, a wrath of god, Armageddon, obliterate, a door of nothingness and a coalition victory. and their all in certain decks.

81991: Final Judgment.author: SpencerDub
81991: Final Judgment.text_parsed:
@TotalDomination - "so pretty much from my understanding, "remove all creatures from the game" should of been "remove all creatures in play from the game". therefore, the card has been misleading and has been used incorrectly unless Wizards reprints it or posts an official ruling, as it has none right now."

Sorry, but that's incorrect. Magic terminology is very specific. A creature card is only considered a creature when it's on the battlefield. When you're holding a Llanowar Elves in your hand, for instance, it's a creature card, not a creature, which is why your opponent can't Doom Blade or Unmake it, and why Hidden Horror asks you to discard a "creature card," not a creature. If a card, like Final Judgment, says "Remove all creatures from the game" (or "Exile all creatures," as it is currently worded), it only applies to creatures, not creature cards, which are the cards in your hand, your library, your graveyard, and in exile.

The card may have been used incorrectly, but that's not the fault of the game; rather, it's due to a misunderstanding of the rules and terminology of Magic.

81991: Final Judgment.author: Sorain

Day of Judgement: When you need to kill everyone on the battlefield, judge them.
Wrath of God: When you need everyone to stay dead, have god judge them.
Final Judgment: When you need them to stay away forever, call O-Kagachi

By far the single strongest answer to creatures, entire armies don't matter to it, protection, undying, persist, regeneration, indestructible, shroud, hex-proof, all are meaningless.

A functional reprint, or a straight reprint for that matter, would be greatly useful. Few other things answer indestructible creatures such as Myr/Darksteel Forge with such authority.

81991: Final Judgment.author: ScytheWrath
81991: Final Judgment.text_parsed:
You guys are all talking about how Final Judgement can and can't exile Progenitus, but what you don't understand is that O-Kagachi (the creature in the art from Final Judgement) IS Progenitus!
The flavor text from Progenitus is "The Soul of the World has returned," and some info on O-Kagachi taken from the MTG Salvation Wiki states that, "It was the soul of the world, the very first kami, as old as the plane itself."
It also says at the end of O-Kagachi's story that he was eventually defeated, and so that would explain how he has returned - even if he returned in a different plane, in a different form.
Is it not absolutely amazing that WOTC made this connection between planes, over (about) 5 years, and no one noticed?!?! Progenitus is just Final Judgement in creature form!!!

If this was common knowledge, could someone please inform me? This just blew my mind, especially figuring it out myself.
81991: Final Judgment.text_posted:
You guys are all talking about how [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard] can and can't exile [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard], but what you don't understand is that O-Kagachi (the creature in the art from [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard]) [i]IS[/i] [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard]!
The flavor text from [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard] is [i]"The Soul of the World has returned,"[/i] and some info on O-Kagachi taken from the MTG Salvation Wiki states that,[i] "It was [u]the soul of the world[/u], the very first kami, as old as the plane itself."[/i]
It also says at the end of O-Kagachi's story that he was eventually defeated, and so that would explain how he has returned - even if he returned in a different plane, in a different form.
Is it not absolutely amazing that WOTC made this connection between planes, over (about) 5 years, and no one noticed?!?!  [autocard]Progenitus[/autocard] is just [autocard]Final Judgement[/autocard] in creature form!!!

If this was common knowledge, could someone please inform me?  This just blew my mind, especially figuring it out myself.

81997: Shuriken.author: GrimjawxRULES
81997: Shuriken.text_parsed:
This has to be one of the biggest art/name fails in the history of Magic; "shuriken" are throwing stars. If you want throwing knifes "kunai" is the right word to use.

That being said, this card has excellent flavor, and it's not half bad either. 2 mana, tap a ninja: deal 2 damage to any creature. This could be useful to clear the way for Ink-Eyes or other strong ninjas that you might have in your deck.

If only the name was right ... Man, if I had any I might even consider crossing out the original name and write "Kunai" next to it. When/if Wizards do a new take on the Kamigawa block (as they're doing with Scars), I for one hope for a reprint of Shuriken, only it's named Kunai instead... and don't they dare printing it with throwing stars in the art ...

81997: Shuriken.author: Shushoto
81997: Shuriken.text_parsed: Undoubtedly flavor is this cards strongsuit. But consider the implications! You can use the equip ability to move Shuriken from one creature to another and then throw it in response to the equip! Your opponent gains control of Shuriken and then Shuriken becomes attached to your creature! You get an extra ping and could could even hit your own creature to gain control again!

81997: Shuriken.text_parsed: Guys, this IS a shuriken. Not all shuriken are frikkin himashuriken (flat, pinwheel types). And this is NOT a kunai. Kunai are not throwing knives but instead are gardening tools that were used as a close range weapon. Manga/anime generally do not have accurate representations of what these tools looked like and artists often borrow from each other rather than relying on historical sources. So stop bashing the art or the name! Thanks.

81997: Shuriken.author: MisterAction
81997: Shuriken.text_parsed:
A ninja in the hand is better than two on the battlefield.

A ninja in the hand is a wonderful thing, piggybacking on another creature's evasion abilities, bouncing a creature which can be cast again for combo potential, taking your opponent by surprise and committing a delightful act of sabotage.

A ninja on the battlefield is a sad affair, out in the open with no inherent way to infiltrate enemy lines, and power and toughness scores insufficient to force their way through or defend their master. Left twiddling their thumbs, they can either throw away their lives on a pointless chump-block or wait for their champion to lead them to victory.

A ninja puts idle hands to good use with shuriken. At best, complete and utter devastation of the opposition's ranks; at worst, a chump-block becomes a trade.

A ninja deck needs ninja. A ninja deck needs cheap evasive creatures to propogate ninja. But with only these, many resources will be wasted. Shuriken provides an outlet for extra mana and wayward ninja in times of stagnation, and this can make all the difference.

81997: Shuriken.author: Telltalereaper
81997: Shuriken.text_parsed: @Kevyyb  ur question has already been answered, I figured I'd explain why...when your buddy activates the cost on the first one (can't do them all at once, things don't happen simultaneously), the tap is part of the cost...it's done even before the ability resolves.  Your buddy can try to respond by using another shuriken, but the creature will already be tapped, and the cost can't be paid.  If it wasn't a cost, but said :shuriken deals 2 damage, blah blah blah, then tap creature: it wouldn't be a cost, and wouldn't happen until the ability resolved...and he could respond with the others.  As it is, He can only use one at a time.

81998: Enshrined Memories.author: aznxknight
81998: Enshrined Memories.text_parsed:
This card is now sort of obsolete thanks to Mirrodin Besieged's Lead the stampede. Unless you have loads of mana, which in most cases you won't, this card isn't worth it.
Enshrined Memories forces you to REVEAL X cards, potentially revealing cards that you don't want to your opponent(s) to see. Yes it allows you to pay any amount for X but is it really worth it? You need to pay a total of 6 mana to do the same thing as Lead the stampede. However Lead the stampede doesn't force you to reveal cards, only the ones that you take. In some cases you probably don't want to put certain creatures in your hand unlike Enshrined Memories which forces you to take no matter what. So overall this card got its usefullness toned down by Mirrodin Besieged's card(plus the card is a uncommon too!)
